=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_412F162|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2019-01-06 10:01 ===
* Id: 412F162
* User: SMcCandlish
* Date: 2018-12-09 20:41:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|872883527|SCI 872883527}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|872883531|STYLE 872883531}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|872883533|POLICY 872883533}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|877467351|SCI 877467351}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|877467357|STYLE 877467357}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|877467358|POLICY 877467358}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Should the names of [[Breed standard|standardized breeds]] of domesticated animals be capitalized on Wikipedia,''' to match the published breed standards?  They presently are, with near uniformity, and the practice is almost universally followed in breeds-specific writing, but notably less often in more general writing (except where a breed name is or contains a proper name like "Ennstal Mountain" or "Siamese").

I've been neutral on the question for several years (though arguing at [[WP:RM]] to follow a particular pattern in the interim, for [[WP:CONSISTENCY]] policy reasons). '''I have collected every single {{lang|la|pro}} or {{lang|la|con}} argument I've encountered on this question, at [[WP:BREEDCASE]]''', immediately below which is an index of previous discussions. This may be worth a skim before you respond to this RfC.  My interest in seeing the question answered by clear community consensus is to close the gaping hole in MOS:LIFE (it needs to either state that standardized breeds are an exception, or that they are not), and to complete the [[MOS:ORGANISMS]] in-depth guideline, which has been stuck in draft state for over six years due to this one question not being resolved (though it is followed aside from the breeds question).<br /><span style="white-space:nowrap;font-family:'Trebuchet MS'">‚Äâ‚Äî‚ÄØ[[User:SMcCandlish|'''SMcCandlish''']] [[User talk:SMcCandlish|‚òè]] [[Special:Contributions/SMcCandlish|¬¢]]‚ÄÉüòº‚ÄÉ</span> 20:41, 9 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_01284EC|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2019-01-06 10:01 ===
* Id: 01284EC
* User: Jc86035
* Date: 2018-12-07 09:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|872475400|POLICY 872475400}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|872475403|TECH 872475403}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|877066901|POLICY 877066901}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|877066904|TECH 877066904}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This RfC concerns the function of {{tl|Authority control}}.
# Should the authority control template link to websites that are not primarily databases (i.e. websites where the primary content is not a database structure)?
# If non-databases should be linked to, should any particular groups of external identifiers be excluded from the template based on the type of content (e.g. news, open wikis, TV broadcasters' listings, social media, ...)?
# Should the template link to databases/websites where anyone can edit or add content without a moderator's permission, such as [[MusicBrainz]], [[IMDb]] and [[Discogs]] (and including sites like [[Twitter]], where the relevant identifiers are user account IDs or post IDs)?
# Should the template link to websites which are not operated by governments or non-profit organizations, such as [[YouTube]], [[AllMusic]], [[Quora]] and the [[New York Times]]?
# <small>(added afterwards)</small> Should a new template be created to show other external links (those not to be included in the authority control template) from Wikidata?
# <small>(added afterwards)</small> If such a template is created: (a) should it be a navbox, a bulleted list, or a comma-separated or horizontal list (like [[:fr:Mod√®le:Bases musique]]); (b) should it group links by their content type; (c) should it only show selected groups of links based on a parameter's input (e.g. news websites, social media, ...); (d) should it accept local values for external identifiers (as opposed to only allowing Wikidata data); (e) should the format "[[Website]]: [https://example.com ID]" or the format "[https://example.com Website]" (or a different format) be used to display links?

[[User:Jc86035|Jc86035]] ([[User talk:Jc86035|talk]]) 09:26, 7 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Equaliser (mathematics)#rfc_FC4E768|Talk:Equaliser (mathematics)]] expired 2019-01-07 23:01 ===
* Id: FC4E768
* User: GeoffreyT2000
* Date: 2018-12-08 22:47:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|872745842|SCI 872745842}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|872745844|STYLE 872745844}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|877317553|SCI 877317553}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|877317557|STYLE 877317557}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
We have an article about [[coequalizer]]s, which are dual to equalizers in category theory. But there is currently a spelling variant inconsistency. Should we therefore harmonize the spelling for [[Equaliser (mathematics)]] and [[Coequalizer]]? If so, then we need to decide whether we should use the British "ise" spelling for both, or the American "ize" spelling for both. On the one hand, if "ise" should be used for both articles, then "Equaliser (mathematics)" should stay at its current spelling and "Coequalizer" should be moved to "Coequaliser". On the other hand, if "ize" should be used for both articles, then "Equaliser (mathematics)" should be moved to "Equalizer (mathematics)" and "Coequalizer" should stay at its current spelling. [[User:GeoffreyT2000|Merry Christmas and Happy New Year, GeoffreyT2000]] ([[User talk:GeoffreyT2000|talk]]) 22:47, 8 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Ms. Marvel (Kamala Khan)#rfc_D8136EA|Talk:Ms. Marvel (Kamala Khan)]] expired 2019-01-08 17:01 ===
* Id: D8136EA
* User: TriiipleThreat
* Date: 2018-12-17 20:47:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|874211675|MEDIA 874211675}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the in the other media section contain brief descriptions of each listed work? For example: "Khan appears in the 2018 animated film, ''Marvel Rising: Secret Warriors''" or "Khan appears as an unlockable playable character in ''Marvel Puzzle Quest'', a [[free-to-play]] [[Tile-matching video game|match 3]] adventure game." Or should a simple ''X appears in Y'' approach be taken?--[[User:TriiipleThreat|TriiipleThreat]] ([[User talk:TriiipleThreat|talk]]) 20:47, 17 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Leap year#rfc_8FAC02C|Talk:Leap year]] expired 2019-01-08 23:01 ===
* Id: 8FAC02C
* User: Kriceslo
* Date: 2018-12-10 09:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|872966069|SCI 872966069}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|872966071|POLICY 872966071}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|877544971|SCI 877544971}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|877544972|POLICY 877544972}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 Should [[Leap Year]] page include a computer programming example on how to calculate leap years? The [[Leap Year]] page is cited by numerous computer programmers [https://www.google.com/search?q=link%3Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fen.wikipedia.org%2Fwiki%2FLeap_year+%22java%22] [https://www.google.com/search?q=link%3Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fen.wikipedia.org%2Fwiki%2FLeap_year+%22c%23%22] and is used as a reference by programmers for information on how to calculate whether a given year is a Leap Year. Editors of the [[Leap Year]] page argue [[WP:NOTHOWTO]] (but nevertheless provide a textual algorithm). However, [[WP:BB]] argues that providing a real programming example in the very place that is turned to by many programmers makes the encyclopedia better ([[WP:FATRAT]]). A single one-line programming example (in the vastly common C programming language) is proposed. ¬ù‚Äî[[User:Kriceslo|Kriceslo]] ([[User talk:Kriceslo|talk]]) 09:38, 10 December 2018 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
I have a question regarding the information presented in this article. Despite knowing the user is actually a [[WP:SOCK|sock]] of a blocked user as seen in this article talkpage, the user actually made some points when he asked the article should only featuring the recent records of the current team while moving the records of the defunct North and South Vietnams team into their respective articles. The user stating that for this article along with the [[Germany national football team|Germany]] team article "are the two only countries whose two football federations in the past united into one as for present unlike the present [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]] and [[North Korea national football team|North Korea]] which is separated under different associations until this day". So should we give a space for him/her to express his opinion on this article and separate the records of the current team with the previous defunct team of Vietnams? Or there is something to do with [[FIFA]] recognition that makes some article records could not be included? Thank you. === [[Talk:Linda Sarsour#rfc_9D4DAC7|Talk:Linda Sarsour]] expired 2019-01-14 08:01 ===
* Id: 9D4DAC7
* User: Sangdeboeuf
* Date: 2018-12-15 07:34:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|873814918|BIO 873814918}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Should any or all of the following statements appear in the article under {{slink|Linda Sarsour|2019 Women's March|nopage=y}}?

{{quote frame |'''A.''' In November 2018, Teresa Shook, the march's founder, called for the Women's March leadership to step down, accusing them of having "allowed anti-Semitism, anti-LBGTQIA sentiment and hateful, racist rhetoric to become a part of the platform by their refusal to separate themselves from groups that espouse these racist, hateful beliefs."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/news/417480-womens-march-founder-teresa-shook-calls-for-linda-sarsour-tamika-mallory-and|title=Women's March founder calls for group's leadership to step down|last=Keller|first=Megan|date=2018-11-19|work=TheHill|access-date=2018-12-03|language=en}}</ref>{{reflist}}}}

{{quote frame |'''B.''' Following Shook's comments, it was reported that "regional chapters, allies and some of the movement‚Äôs most visible supporters" had "turned their backs on the national group."<ref name="Lang">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/anger-over-farrakhan-ties-prompts-calls-for-womens-march-leaders-to-resign/2018/11/21/6d925942-edb4-11e8-8679-934a2b33be52_story.html|title=Anger over Farrakhan ties prompts calls for Women‚Äôs March leaders to resign|last1=Marissa J.|first1=Lang|date=November 21, 2018|work=The Washington Post}}</ref>{{reflist}}}}

{{quote frame |'''C.''' Sarsour initially criticized Shook but later apologized to supporters of the march, saying, ‚ÄúWe should have been faster and clearer in helping people understand our values and our commitment to fighting anti-semitism. We regret that‚Äù. She added, "Every member of our movement matters to us ‚Äî including our incredible Jewish and LGBTQ members. We are deeply sorry for the harm we have caused, but we see you, we love you, and we are fighting with you.‚Äù<ref name="Sales November 2018">{{cite news|url=https://www.jta.org/2018/11/20/news-opinion/linda-sarsour-apologizes-jewish-members-womens-march|title=Linda Sarsour apologizes to Jewish members of the Women‚Äôs March|last=Sales|first=Ben|date=November 20, 2018|agency=Jewish Telegraphic Agency}}</ref>{{reflist}}}} ‚Äî[[User:Sangdeboeuf|Sangdeboeuf]] ([[User talk:Sangdeboeuf|talk]]) 07:34, 15 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Digital dependencies and global mental health#rfc_6F54719|Talk:Digital dependencies and global mental health]] expired 2019-01-14 15:01 ===
* Id: 6F54719
* User: E.3
* Date: 2019-01-10 05:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|877680486|LANG 877680486}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|877680491|SOC 877680491}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|878385993|LANG 878385993}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|878385995|SOC 878385995}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have disclosed my COI numerous times. There is a lot of linguistic misunderstandings and scientific understandings around linguistics in regard to the digital dependencies, specifically "addiction" vs "dependence", "social media addiction" as a "diagnostic category", and several others are notable. I'd like to know whether we are able to mention the psychiatric category of ADHD whilst commenting that a prominent psychologist is suggesting a meta scientific ontological discussion about the whole diagnostic category, under the psychology section. Finally there is one very high quality trial about ADHD symptoms and "digital media use" that explain only correlations and do not draw conclusions. It's not allowed to be on either this page or [[social media addiction]] which I suggest may not give it weight. This may give false balance to the non existence of a correlation with "symptoms" only. I am trying to consider all [[WP:MEDRS]] policies and especially [[WP:SYNTH]] policies here very carefully. I cannot do this on my own. Thankyou very much to all involved contributors! [[User:E.3|E.3]] ([[User talk:E.3|talk]]) 05:16, 10 January 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Social media addiction#rfc_92D64BE|Talk:Social media addiction]] expired 2019-01-14 15:01 ===
* Id: 92D64BE
* User: E.3
* Date: 2019-01-09 14:41:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|877575080|POLICY 877575080}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|878385996|POLICY 878385996}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is a lot of confusion in my opinion in this page as to how MEDRS applies. We have a high quality, well reported (worldwide reported and cited) about social media (Pokemon Go) namely being correlated but not causative to ADHD. They don't say the three words "social media addiction" in this study. Therefore ADHD is not allowed to be mentioned, and the rest of the previous edits I have made become worthless. I have removed all [[WP:SYNTH]] as best as I am able with the kind assistance of these same editors. 
EU Consensus statement around ADHD states internet use. But not "social media addiction". Also hyper focus causing problematic internet use. Not "social media addiction" No meta analysis around ADHD is allowed to be used. Nothing from any other field is allowed to be used because of MEDRS, which is why I created [[digital dependencies and global mental health]]. This page always has content removed, sometimes appropriately, but [[digital addict]] does not. I have just discussed with some experts and that is because they are moving away from this terminology, being so stigmatising to the afflicted people. It however means we are unable to use any reliable source such as guidelines, EU consensus statements, metaanalyses etc. 
I am the only person really adding anything to the page, everyone reads MEDRS slightly differently as to how it applies here. This is a unique page in regard to MEDRS because it is so current. It is of high importance, regardless of what the portals in this page have stated. The suggestions I was given to add re internet addiction metaanalyses were already deleted prior to the suggestion, because of the linguistics. Expert opinion (even when they all say the same thing, using slightly different words) is deleted. I think we need clarification from uninvolved editors as to how MEDRS applies to this, and whether exemptions may apply. This is a high importance medical issue, and we cannot with this impasse make it encyclopedic at all, in my opinion the article as it stands is useless. [[User:E.3|E.3]] ([[User talk:E.3|talk]]) 14:41, 9 January 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion#rfc_0FDA1FF|Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion]] expired 2019-01-14 20:01 ===
* Id: 0FDA1FF
* User: Lojbanist
* Date: 2018-12-21 16:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|874804867|PROP 874804867}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|878431533|PROP 878431533}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Renumber G13 to D1 and create the following new Draft CSD:

'''D2: Any draft that would be subject to speedy deletion as an article'''

Any draft that would fail any of the active criteria for speedy deletion of articles is valid under this criterion. When deleting or nominating a draft page under this criterion, remember to indicate which article CSD criterion applies to it. <nowiki>{{Db-d2|criterion}}</nowiki>

'''D3: Blatant misuse of Wikipedia as a web host'''

Pages in draftspace consisting of writings, information, discussions, and/or activities not closely related to Wikipedia's goals, where the owner has made few or no edits outside of draftspace, with the exception of plausible drafts. It applies regardless of the age of the page in question. <nowiki>{{Db-d3}}, {{Db-draftu5}}</nowiki>

[[User:Lojbanist|'''Kamafa Delgato''']] <sub>([[User:Lojbanist|Lojbanist]])</sub><sup>[[User talk:Lojbanist|Styrofoam is not made from kittens.]]</sup> 16:02, 21 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Tamika Mallory#rfc_2A5F686|Talk:Tamika Mallory]] expired 2019-01-15 00:02 ===
* Id: 2A5F686
* User: ModerateMike729
* Date: 2018-12-28 02:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|875652535|POL 875652535}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|875894637|BIO 875894637}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|880378359|POL 880378359}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
After several weeks there has been no progress toward consensus on this issue so I'm making a request for comments: Should the fact that Mallory has faced accusations of anti-semitism for associating with Louis Farrakhan and the Nation of Islam be included in the lede?

Reliable sources including the [https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/23/us/womens-march-anti-semitism.html New York Times,] the [https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/opinion/page/ct-perspec-page-chicago-womens-march-louis-farrakhan-donald-trump-tamika-mallory-20181226-story.html Chicago Tribune], and the [https://www.jpost.com/American-Politics/Womens-March-facing-unknown-challenges-with-antisemitism-allegations-575247 Jerusalem Post], among a number of others have written on the issue. They cite Mallory's ties to [[Farrakhan]] and the [[Nation of Islam]], both of which hold anti-semitic views including that Jews are "satanic". In fact, I'm struggling to find a single reliable source that has written about Mallory in the past year that ''doesn't'' discuss the Farrakhan/NOI ties. Thoughts? [[User:ModerateMike729|ModerateMike729]] ([[User talk:ModerateMike729|talk]]) 02:46, 28 December 2018 (UTC)}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|873966442|PROP 873966442}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=

=== [[Template talk:Selfref#rfc_3A6A3BF|Template talk:Selfref]] expired 2019-01-15 07:01 ===
* Id: 3A6A3BF
* User: Cunard
* Date: 2018-12-16 06:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|873966437|POLICY 873966437}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|873966439|TECH 873966439}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|878509889|POLICY 878509889}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|878509891|TECH 878509891}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should we make this template hidden in the article mainspace with a code to those who doesn't logged in, especially readers? The articles that linked using this template are mostly only in the interest of the editors and often distract the readers who come here only to read (example: [[Fair use]], [[Internet troll]], [[International Phonetic Alphabet]]). We already put links to the project page at the left bar and from the Main Page. Some would probably argue that this hatnote would attract new editors, however that's not our purpose, our purpose is to create an encyclopedia. Per [[Wikipedia:Hatnote]]: "Their purpose is to help readers locate a different article if the one they are at is not the one they're looking for", most readers not even intended to look for the project namespace in the first place. This discussion is almost similar to [[WP:CNR]]. <small>RfC relisted by [[User:Cunard|Cunard]] ([[User talk:Cunard|talk]]) at 06:33, 16 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Kensh?#rfc_BCD6B02|Talk:Kensh?]] expired 2019-01-15 13:01 ===
* Id: BCD6B02
* User: Karma Dechen Lhamo
* Date: 2018-12-16 12:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|873997015|RELI 873997015}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|878546451|RELI 878546451}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
===Request'''

'''The article should to be changed to refect the following:'''

'''The more recent accounts section should include:'''

Jiyu-Kennett Roshi, a 20th-century Soto Zen Master who was the first Western female Zen Master, and founded both Shasta and Throssel Hole Abbeys, published a highly detailed personal account of her kensho experiences in her book, ''How to Grow a Lotus Blossom''{{sfn|Kennett|1993|}}. In it, she described three different stages of kensho experience, along with a fourth that can occur at the time of death:
#A first stage, "initial glimpse" kensho, that most Zen practitioners eventually experience, and that are often used as the later basis for qualification for Dharma Transmission
#A second, ongoing Fugen kensho or, "the little moments that make one dance"{{sfn|Kennett|1993|}} experienced by practitioners with a continual, stable practice 
#A third stage kensho, that can involve past life recall, profound spiritual visions, and deep awakening experiences that go beyond what is experienced in the first kensho.

Finally a fourth stage is described as Parinirvana itself, experienced by rare practitioners who achieve Buddhahood upon time of death.{{sfn|Kennett|1993|}} 
{{quote|"In the first kensh≈ç the stages flash by so quickly that the whole kensh≈ç is only comprehended as one flash. One goes, as it were, from earth to heaven by rocket, or as a lightning bolt, with no time to take notice of the journey before one has arrived. The third kensh≈ç takes place slowly and deliberately with plenty of time to comprehend each step of the way. For example, in the first kensh≈ç one jumps, of necessity, beyond the opposites and ''knows'' for ever afterwards that one ''has'' jumped. In the third kensh≈ç the opposites are looked at slowly and dispassionately and then ''deliberately'' discarded; the first kensh≈ç is a swift comprehension of grace; the third kensh≈ç ''starts'' as a ''deliberate'' act of will." {{sfn|Kennett|1993|p=xxiv-xxv}}}}
Her description of kensho stages is interesting, in that it closely parallels those of Dzogchen and Theravada stages as well. 

'''Reasoning:'''
Because Jiyu-Kennett was a highly influential and Zen Master, famous for being the first western woman to become a Zen master, and she also established a two training monasteries, and dozens of temples and meditation groups worldwide which continue to be a sizable portion of the Soto Zen world. She is also the only person to my knowledge who ever published an entire book on the subject of kensho, and had numerous unique experiences on the matter, which are of relevance to this article. Additionally, adding a woman's perspective on kensho, increases the diversity of views, and historically, women's views within Zen have not been as well represented.

'''Additionally, the subsection on Soto Zen views should be updated with this information as well. Reasoning: consistency in the article.'''

'''Additionally, the section at the end related to similarities to other traditions should be include sections on the four visions under Dzogchen:'''

The Japanese term kensho is similar to the Dzogchen teachings of the Four Visions.

The '''four visions''' (Tib. [[‡Ω¶‡æ£‡ΩÑ‡ºã‡Ωñ‡ºã‡Ωñ‡Ωû‡Ω≤‡ºã]], ''nangwa shyi'', [[Wyl.]] ''snang ba bzhi'') of [[t√∂gal]] are:

#direct realization of reality itself (Tib. [[‡ΩÜ‡Ωº‡Ω¶‡ºã‡Ωâ‡Ω≤‡Ωë‡ºã‡Ωò‡ΩÑ‡Ωº‡Ωì‡ºã‡Ω¶‡Ω¥‡Ωò‡ºã]], ''ch√∂nyi ng√∂n sum''; Wyl. ''chos nyid mngon sum'')
#increasing experience (Tib. [[‡Ωâ‡Ωò‡Ω¶‡ºã‡ΩÇ‡Ωº‡ΩÑ‡ºã‡Ω†‡Ωï‡Ω∫‡Ω£‡ºã]], ''nyam gong pel''; Wyl. ''nyams gong ‚Äòphel'')	
#awareness reaching full maturity (Tib. [[‡Ω¢‡Ω≤‡ΩÇ‡ºã‡Ωî‡ºã‡Ωö‡Ωë‡ºã‡Ωï‡Ω∫‡Ωñ‡Ω¶‡ºã]], ''rigpa ts√© pep''; Wyl. ''rig pa tshad phebs'')
#dissolution of experience into the nature of reality (Tib. [[‡ΩÜ‡Ωº‡Ω¶‡ºã‡Ωâ‡Ω≤‡Ωë‡ºã‡Ωü‡Ωë‡ºã‡Ω¶‡ºã]], ''ch√∂nyi z√©sa'', ''ch√∂nyi z√©pa'' or ''ch√∂z√© lod√©''; Wyl.''chos nyid zad sa'')

The Dzogchen-traditions states that the ultimate nature of all sentient beings is ''pure, all-encompassing, primordial awareness'', or ''naturally occurring timeless awareness''. This intrinsic awareness has no form of its own, and yet is capable of perceiving, experiencing, reflecting, or expressing all form. It does so without being affected by those forms in any ultimate, permanent way.

The analogy given by Dzogchen masters is that one's nature is like a mirror which reflects with complete openness, but is not affected by the reflections. [[Rigpa]] is the knowledge that ensues from recognizing this mirror-like clarity,{{sfn|Namdak|2006|p=97}} which cannot be found by searching nor identified.{{sfn|Third Dzogchen Rinpoche|2008|p=152}} One ''knows'' that there is a primordial freedom from grasping his or her mind.{{sfn|Namdak|2006|p=144-145}}

'''Reasoning'''
The Four Visions are of direct similarity and therefor would be of relevance and interest to readers of the article.

{{reflist-talk}}

[[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kensh≈ç&diff=873969947&oldid=873968328 diff]]
[[User:Karma Dechen Lhamo|Karma Dechen Lhamo]] ([[User talk:Karma Dechen Lhamo|talk]]) 12:54, 16 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Articles for deletion#rfc_E74C702|Wikipedia talk:Articles for deletion]] expired 2019-01-16 18:01 ===
* Id: E74C702
* User: Otr500
* Date: 2018-12-17 17:47:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|874184339|POLICY 874184339}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|878742323|POLICY 878742323}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
*Closing AFD as keep with instructions that merge can be handled at the article.

:I have seen this more than once on an article at AFD, an example concerning duplicate content at [[WP:Articles for deletion/Tabiti]], that can result in a [[WP:NOT#DICTIONARY|dictionary entry]], when there is clear evidence leaning towards merge, or where merge was a better option, or needed for obvious policy and guideline reasoning, and it was closed as "Keep" supposedly because merge can be discussed on the article talk page. 
:The lead on this main page includes "Merge": ''"Common outcomes are that the article is kept, merged, redirected, incubated, renamed/moved to another title, userfied to a user subpage, or deleted per the deletion policy. Disambiguation pages are also nominated for deletion at AfD."''. 
:[[WP:ATD-M]] states ''"If two pages are duplicates or otherwise redundant, one should be merged and redirected to the other, using the most common, or more general page name. '''This does not require process or formal debate beforehand'''."''. A reason for a merge option at AFD is because local editors (consensus) can turn this into a battle on its own. A note at WP:ATD-M:

*''Note that an outcome of "merge and delete" may potentially cause licensing problems if attribution for the merged content is lost in the process. The essay [[Wikipedia:Merge and delete]] discusses this, whereas the essay [[Wikipedia:Delete or merge]] discusses a different case that causes no such licensing problems.''.
This clearly shows merge as an AFD option, and if performed by an admin removes battleground issues and listed potential licensing problems. 

:It does not seem logical to make a process circular so that an end result is aggravation, loss of editor interest, editors not wanting to add merge as an option, and articles remaining that should not exist. On Wikipedia there is "Keep" and "Delete". Any consensus other than "keep" is a delete no matter how you look at it. If an article at AFD has two "keeps", one "delete", and two "Merge" or "redirect" it will likely result in "no consensus". I don't see the confusion because anything other than keep is still a delete so it would seem this would dictate consideration. That is just my opinion but might edge editors to agree more to merge.  
:There needs to be some clarity on ignoring valid merge criterion and remanding an article back to local consensus for a circular battle. Attempts at [[WP:cleanup|cleanup]] should not have to be so complicated and in fact this is counter to above policy. If there is some Admin reasoning not shared with editors it would be good to know this.  [[User:Otr500|Otr500]] ([[User talk:Otr500|talk]]) 17:47, 17 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_D9FC20F|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2019-01-16 22:01 ===
* Id: D9FC20F
* User: Headbomb
* Date: 2018-12-17 21:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|874220901|POLICY 874220901}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|874220904|TECH 874220904}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|874220907|PROP 874220907}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|878782196|POLICY 878782196}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|878782198|TECH 878782198}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|878782199|PROP 878782199}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This is a proposal to increase date consistency in citations, per [[MOS:DATEUNIFY]]. Specifically, a bot would look for templates like
*{{tl|Use dmy dates}}
*{{tl|Use mdy dates}}
and bring present dates in line with desired usage on that specific article. I would make a [[WP:BOTREQ]] for this, but I'd rather go in with a consensus that this is desired, and what scope is OK with the community. Note that the below is just the general idea/goal, there will be odd cases and kinks that need to be ironed out. That's what the [[WP:BOTAPPROVAL|bot trial]] would help with. If nothing reliable can be made, then the bot wouldn't get approved. <span style="font-variant:small-caps; whitespace:nowrap;">[[User:Headbomb|Headbomb]] {[[User talk:Headbomb|t]] ¬∑ [[Special:Contributions/Headbomb|c]] ¬∑ [[WP:PHYS|p]] ¬∑ [[WP:WBOOKS|b]]}</span> 21:25, 17 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_94E05DA|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2019-01-16 22:01 ===
* Id: 94E05DA
* User: Pkbwcgs
* Date: 2018-12-31 10:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|876133245|PROP 876133245}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|878967353|PROP 878967353}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I can do this using my bot. There is a feature on WPCleaner called "Update ISBN warning messages" on WPCleaner. I have been having a discussion about this feature around two weeks ago. The discussion can be found [[Wikipedia talk:WPCleaner#ISBN warnings]]. The feature adds and removes ISBN warning messages on the talk pages of the affected articles. It tells the ISBN that is affected and it also tell the reason why the ISBN is affected. This will help Wikipedians fix ISBNs much more easily on English Wikipedia. The template is at [[User:NicoV/ISBN Warning]] at the moment. This needs to be moved to [[:Template:ISBN warning]]. The talk pages with an ISBN warning message will be added into [[:Category:Articles with invalid ISBNs]]. The WPCleaner script can add the warning message for the affected articles and remove the warning message for the articles that have been fixed automatically. I have tested this on [[User:Pkbwcgs/sandbox|my sandbox]] and it works. This feature is already available on French Wikipedia and [[User:NicoV]] kindly said that he can configure WPCleaner so that this can also happen at the English Wikipedia. The output looks like this:<br/>
{{User:NicoV/ISBN Warning|0-123-456-78|The ISBN has only nine digits instead of ten so it is invalid.}}
Shall we have this brilliant feature which will help the identification of incorrect ISBNs on English Wikipedia? [[User:Pkbwcgs|Pkbwcgs]] ([[User talk:Pkbwcgs|talk]]) 10:19, 31 December 2018 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:Pocket universe#rfc_20FE8F8|Talk:Pocket universe]] expired 2019-01-17 02:01 ===
* Id: 20FE8F8
* User: LaundryPizza03
* Date: 2018-12-18 01:33:00

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
(Copied from notice at [[WT:COMICS]] and [[WT:SF]], with slight modifications for relevance.)

I note that [[Pocket universe]] is no longer within the scope of this project since the fiction-related content was [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pocket_universe&diff=796927060&oldid=790589653 removed] in August 2017 (as "pop culture trivia"); the remaining content is exclusively about real-world [[cosmological inflation]]. However, many fiction-related topics, presumably mostly within the science-fiction genre, [[Special:WhatLinksHere/Pocket_universe|still link here]] despite the fact that there is no more fiction-related content. What shall be done with these links?

Both [[WP:SF|WikiProject Science Fiction]] and [[WP:COMICS|WikiProject Comics]] have been notified. ‚Äì[[User:LaundryPizza03|'''<font color=#7f7fbf>Laundry</font><font color=#ffbf00>Pizza</font><font color=#bf0000>03</font>''']] ([[User talk:LaundryPizza03|<font color=#00df00>d</font>]][[Special:Contributions/LaundryPizza03|<font color=#00bfff>c&#x0304;</font>]]) 01:33, 18 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Sweetener World Tour#rfc_52785B2|Talk:Sweetener World Tour]] expired 2019-01-19 17:01 ===
* Id: 52785B2
* User: livelikemusic
* Date: 2018-12-20 16:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|876812601|MEDIA 876812601}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|879190031|MEDIA 879190031}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am here to address some issues within the article. "Location" should be used, as it is a valid parameter per {{TI|Infobox concert}}. If anything, the division of "total number of dates" should just state the total amount. Infoboxes are meant to present an overdue of data. If visitors want to know the exact amount of dates, they can go below and see them. As much, "world" is proper for "type" of tour, as this is a world tour and is promoted as such. Yes, it is a concert tour, but it is also a "world" tour ‚Äî see good-article [[War Tour]] for an example. In addition, the removal of "end date" is wrong, as the end date, as of now, is known. If additional dates are added, it can be changed. As such, {{TI|TableTBA}} should be used, as it is visually built for tables to match the table set up. Not to mention, using "rowspan" for the attendance is wrong, as each date is separate, and it implies that BOTH dates will share the same data, which they will likely not. '''<span style="font-size:85%;">[[User:livelikemusic|<span style="color:#ab83ab">livelikemusic</span>]]</span>''' <span style="font-size:85%;">[[User talk:livelikemusic|<span style="color:CadetBlue">talk!</span>]]</span> 16:46, 20 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Warship#rfc_D60C374|Talk:Warship]] expired 2019-01-19 18:01 ===
* Id: D60C374
* Date: 2018-12-20 17:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|874653148|HIST 874653148}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|874653152|POL 874653152}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|879198356|HIST 879198356}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|879198362|POL 879198362}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The scope of the article currently encompasses "ships that engage in combat". However, [[Talk:Warship/Archive_1#Definition_of_a_warship|this discussion about the definition of ''Warship'']] mentions that the [[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea]] defines ''Warship'' as (roughly) "ships that are owned by a military, regardless of combatant status". In view of this, should the scope of this title be about "ships that engage in combat" (aka [[Combatant ship]]) or "ships that are owned by a military" (aka [[Naval ship]])? ‚Äî'''[[User:Madrenergic|Madrenergic]]'''<sup>[[User_talk:Madrenergic|talk]]</sup> 17:10, 20 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:K√§tlin Aas#rfc_A95345D|Talk:K√§tlin Aas]] expired 2019-01-20 00:02 ===
* Id: A95345D
* User: Trillfendi
* Date: 2019-01-13 05:24:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|878131292|BIO 878131292}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|879243943|BIO 879243943}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Let‚Äôs analyze, objectively, can we, everyone. Now 11 of the sources given here are of models.com slides. Some Wikipedia administrators express that models.com is not a reliable source. 1 source is fashionmodeldirectory.com aka the IMDb of models. Some administrators express that fashionmodeldirectory is not a reliable source, to stand on its own. 1 source given is Fashionista.com, with a one sentence quote. I‚Äôve never seen Fashionista.com, which is a blog, considered as a reliable source. 1 source, which admittedly I placed years ago is of YouTube (goes without saying). 1 source is NYMag‚Äôs model profile which is not used to contribute to notability, if it really is for notability then the same logic can be used to refund the page of [http://nymag.com/fashion/models/jdunstall/juliadunstall/ Julia Dunstall]. 4 sources are simply slideshows of runway shows that are not editorials for Vogue magazine or even remotely related to Vogue magazins itself but for some reason wrongly identified as such. 1 source is about Prada‚Äôs casting standard where the subject is mentioned as part of a small group, while others get whole paragraphs. 1 source is T Magazine by NYT who ask her questions like ‚ÄúTwitter or Instagram?‚Äù and ‚Äúwhat time do you get out of bed?‚Äù So that '''only leaves''' Vogue Italia, who has a brief career summary with a slideshow of runway shows. Having that only one independent source is not in any regard enough for general notability or significant coverage for a page. In any way shape or form. That‚Äôs why I [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/K√§tlin Aas|proposed deletion of this page]].

So how, under these circumstances, has the article ‚Äúimproved‚Äù in quality or general notability in any way? When that same standard was previously used to reject model articles with actual [[WP:SIGCOV|significant coverage]] such as [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ari_Westphal&oldid=837430824 Ari Westphal], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Jing_Wen&oldid=796000617 Jing Wen], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Alanna_Arrington&oldid=837757887 Alanna Arrington], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Maartje_Verhoef&oldid=773873373 Maartje Verhoef], and [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Willow_Hand&oldid=819579194 Willow Hand], and [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Duckie_Thot&oldid=838638374 Duckie Thot], who had these same sources? Comments included ‚Äúappearances do not contribute to notability‚Äù, ‚ÄúNot notable sources. Simply announcements and profiles,‚Äù and ‚ÄúNot satisfying our simplest standards as the sources are simply announcements, profiles, notices or similar; there's no automatic inherited notability from anything or anyone.‚Äù

Bear in mind, none of this is personal I‚Äôm just looking for clarity on it. [[User:Trillfendi|Trillfendi]] ([[User talk:Trillfendi|talk]]) 05:24, 13 January 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Blocking policy#rfc_8785E3D|Wikipedia talk:Blocking policy]] expired 2019-01-20 08:01 ===
* Id: 8785E3D
* User: TonyBallioni
* Date: 2018-12-21 07:34:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|874742591|POLICY 874742591}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|879290198|POLICY 879290198}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
As {{code|unblockself}} is now gone but sysops now have the ability to block the admin that blocked them instead, I think it makes sense to update the blocking policy to include language making this clear that it is only to be done in exceptional circumstances such as a compromise and never for the purpose of extending a dispute or getting revenge on the other party: namely since it‚Äôs functionally replaces unblockself, it should be viewed through policy as such. Therefore I am proposing the following be added to the blocking policy:
{{talkquote|Administrators who are blocked have the technical ability to block the administrator who blocked their own account. This ability should only be used in exceptional circumstances, such as account compromises, where there is a clear and immediate need. Use of the block tool to further a dispute or retaliate against the original blocking administrator is not allowed.}}
[[User:TonyBallioni|TonyBallioni]] ([[User talk:TonyBallioni|talk]]) 07:34, 21 December 2018 (UTC)}}

'''A''': Nothing.

'''B''':<blockquote>In 1996, the ADL settled a federal civil lawsuit filed by groups representing African Americans and Arab Americans, that alleged that the ADL hired agents with police ties to gather information. The ADL did not admit any wrongdoing, but agreed to a restraining injunction barring the ADL from obtaining information from state employees who are forbidden by law to divulge such information. === [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_5313843|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2019-01-22 21:03 ===

* User: 83.104.51.74#top

{{rfcquote|text=
</nowiki>
There‚Äôs been a reversion war on [[Slavery in India]], primarily due to the credibility of sources, see: [[Talk:Slavery in India%23Manusmriti]], which per {{U|Kautilya3}} suggestion I‚Äôll raise here. What qualifications must an author have, to reliably translate, and comment on a two millennia old work, and does a published commentary, on a Sanskrit work constitute a review, or is it still a Primary work; in the example above, is ‚Äò‚ÄôManusmriti with the Commentary of Medhatithi, by [[Ganganath Jha]], 1920, ISBN-10: 8120811550‚Äô‚Äô, a reliable, non primary source, that‚Äôs been authored, and published by qualified entities, and in particular whether the following excerpt can be considered reliable [https://www.wisdomlib.org/hinduism/book/manusmriti-with-the-commentary-of-medhatithi/d/doc201350.html Verse 8.415]<ref>Manusmriti with the Commentary of Medhatithi, by [[Ganganath Jha]], 1920, {{ISBN|8120811550}}</ref>, and current. -- <small class="autosigned">‚Äî&nbsp;Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:83.104.51.74|83.104.51.74]] ([[User talk:83.104.51.74#top|talk]] ‚Ä¢ [[Special:Contributions/83.104.51.74|contribs]]) </small>

{{reflist talk}}

* '''Comment''' The user has been told that [[Manusmriti]], a quasi-religious text from 200 AD, is a PRIMARY source no matter who translated it when, which he finds hard to accept. He also believes that it can be used to justify edits like [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Slavery_in_India&diff=879320053&oldid=879314724 this] (at [[Slavery in India]]). -- [[User:Kautilya3|Kautilya3]] ([[User talk:Kautilya3|talk]]) 23:41, 21 January 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Name pages#rfc_2835914|Wikipedia talk:Name pages]] expired 2019-01-24 19:01 ===
* Id: 2835914
* User: Coastside
* Date: 2019-01-24 08:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|879930887|UNSORTED 879930887}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|880003637|UNSORTED 880003637}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 This is a request for comment on a proposed guideline for handling name pages.  This guideline applies existing policy and accepted practice in a referenceable way.  It is needed because these policies are often confused, similar questions are raised repeatedly, and policies are misapplied.  In particular there is need to differentiate between name index articles and disambiguation pages. This is a guideline and does not introduce new policy.  It is a how-to guide for existing policy and accepted community standards with examples. [[User:Coastside|Coastside]] ([[User talk:Coastside|talk]]) 08:40, 24 January 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Administrators' noticeboard#rfc_B94B334|Wikipedia:Administrators' noticeboard]] expired 2019-01-24 20:01 ===
* Id: B94B334
* Date: 2019-01-17 21:07:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|878937194|PROP 878937194}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|880012286|PROP 880012286}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Put in place an initially voluntary structure to manage discussions on bans and editing restrictions, as follows:
# A templated header (using mandatory SUBST and date substitution like deletion templates) which sets an expectation that an ANI debate on a named sanction will run for at least 7 days, with, as always, the possibility of an early close per [[WP:SNOW]], but a strong expectation that this would normally only happen when the proposal is ''rejected''. The offset to this would be...
# An optional "temporary injunction" which enacts the requested sanction immediately without prejudice during the debate - thus an IBAN, TBAN or block would be put in place until the debate is concluded, then either lifted without implication of wrongdoing or made permanent depending on the outcome. This would be requested by the filing party and then reviewed by an uninvolved admin, as with arbitration sanctions
So, run ANI block/ban discussions much more on the lines of AE, but with ANI's bigger audience. 21:07, 17 January 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography#rfc_525E30E|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Biography]] expired 2019-01-26 04:01 ===
* Id: 525E30E
* User: Cyphoidbomb
* Date: 2019-01-24 16:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|879984846|BIO 879984846}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|879984854|MEDIA 879984854}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|879984862|SOC 879984862}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|880223906|BIO 880223906}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|880223908|MEDIA 880223908}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|880223912|SOC 880223912}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What are the criteria for including an award in a biographical article, like in an Accolades section or a List of awards won article?

* '''A)''' - Any award may be included if sourced.
* '''B)''' - Any award from an organization with established notability is sufficient for inclusion.
* '''C)''' - Notability of the specific award must be previously established, i.e. an article on the award must first exist.
* '''D)''' - Some other criteria TBD
[[User:Cyphoidbomb|Cyphoidbomb]] ([[User talk:Cyphoidbomb|talk]]) 16:26, 24 January 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Ersan ?lyasova#rfc_DA2520E|Talk:Ersan ?lyasova]] expired 2019-01-26 23:01 ===
* Id: DA2520E
* User: DA1
* Date: 2018-12-27 22:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|875628629|BIO 875628629}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|875628631|POL 875628631}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|875628635|SOC 875628635}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|880346832|BIO 880346832}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|880346839|POL 880346839}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|880346844|SOC 880346844}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The article of a basketball player [[Ersan_ƒ∞lyasova#Personal_life|has a section describing]] an incident where Uzbekistan made an arbitration bid that the subject is an Uzbekistani national. The court instead ruled in Turkey's favor. The details are all well except the last line.
:: Other biographies, while not claiming an Uzbek birth, still maintain a 1984 birth year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://qha.com.ua/en/sport/life-history-of-crimean-tatar-basketball-player/55452/|title=Life history of Crimean Tatar basketball player|publisher=|accessdate=22 January 2017}}{{dead link|date=December 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:M0tueEACt0oJ:qha.com.ua/en/sport/life-history-of-crimean-tatar-basketball-player/55452/+&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us|title=Life history of Crimean Tatar basketball player - Crimean News Agency|author=|date=|website=webcache.googleusercontent.com|accessdate=27 December 2018}}</ref>

This is a singular cited article (same cite repeated twice) but the language used is in the plural. The cited article has also been pulled (dead link) but the language used ("other biographies...still maintain") is in the present-tense. Bios are supposed to be up-to-date, we shouldn't rely on a pulled link from the past on a controversial statement (which may or may not be accurate) to make a present-tense statement.

Nonetheless, even if we have additional cites we add in, it is still a dueweight issue because the lines before it already describe the dispute/incident in a concise and neutral manner. Why is the article '''repeating''' on a point as if to hammer it in? This is UNDUEWEIGHT. 

Additionally, I have noticed another issue. The paragraph at first describes "The controversy is fueled by the claim that a man named Arsen Illyasov..." then in the next line states that Uzbekistan made this argument to the court. The fact that this argument presented by Uzbekistan is where the controversy stems from, it '''should be disclosed first''' and ''then'' the claim should be detailed. Not the other way around. I believe this also violates [[WP:DUE]], which states:
{{quote frame|1=Undue weight can be given in several ways, including but not limited to depth of detail, quantity of text, prominence of placement, juxtaposition of statements and imagery.}}

This was my initial edit: [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ersan_%C4%B0lyasova&diff=875398906&oldid=875021399] It was reverted and we have a dispute between us. [[User:DA1|DA1]] ([[User talk:DA1|talk]]) 22:11, 27 December 2018 (UTC)}}

* Id: 90E76FD
* User: Huldra
* Date: 2018-12-27 23:20:00

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the lead say:

*Option B: "for arguing that the [[White Helmets (Syrian Civil War)|White Helmets]] stage rescues"

=== [[Talk:The Washington Times#rfc_D26577F|Talk:The Washington Times]] expired 2019-01-27 03:01 ===
* Id: D26577F
* User: Marquis de Faux
* Date: 2018-12-28 02:41:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|875652532|MEDIA 875652532}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|875753661|POL 875753661}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|880378356|MEDIA 880378356}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|880378359|POL 880378359}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the text in bold be included in the lede paragraph?

Throughout its history, ''The Times'' has been known for its [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] political stance.<ref name="Hall" /><ref name="Glaberson" /><ref name=":0" /><ref name=":5" /> It has drawn controversy for publishing racially charged content, including racially incendiary commentary and [[conspiracy theories]] about United States president [[Barack Obama]].<ref name="Betsy Woodruff">{{Cite web|author=Betsy Woodruff|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/cruzs-cozy-ties-to-dcs-most-prominent-paranoid-islamophobe|title=Cruz‚Äôs Cozy Ties To DC's Most Prominent, Paranoid Islamophobe|work=Daily Beast|date=December 15, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Bump">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2015/12/08/meet-frank-gaffney-the-anti-muslim-gadfly-who-produced-donald-trumps-anti-muslim-poll/|title=Meet Frank Gaffney, the anti-Muslim gadfly reportedly advising Donald Trump‚Äôs transition team|last=Bump|first=Philip|date=November 16, 2016|work=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref name="Eli Clifton">{{Cite web|author=Eli Clifton|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2015/12/08/donald-trump-frank-gaffney-islamophobia-poll/|title=Meet Donald Trump's Islamophobia Expert|website=Foreign Policy|date=December 8, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Robert Schlesinger">{{Cite web|author=Robert Schlesinger|url=https://www.usnews.com/opinion/blogs/robert-schlesinger/2009/06/09/the-nutty-obama-is-a-muslim-charge-is-back-now-with-a-hitler-comparison|title=The Nutty 'Obama Is a Muslim' Charge Is Back (Now With a Hitler Comparison!)|work=U.S. News & World Report|date=June 9, 2009}}</ref><ref name="Nyhan">{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/brendan-nyhan/pundits-blame-the-victims_b_692327.html|title=Pundits Blame the Victims on Obama Muslim Myth|website=Huffington Post|date=August 24, 2010|author=Brendan Nyhan}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://archives.cjr.org/united_states_project/the_washington_times_takes_a_b.php|title=''The Washington Times'' takes a giant step‚Äîbackwards|last=Blake|first=Mariah|date=February 11, 2013|work=Columbia Journalism Review|access-date=2018-06-29|language=en}}</ref> '''It has published many columns rejecting the scientific consensus on [[climate change]].'''<ref name="Playing Climate-Change Telephone">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/tech/elements/playing-climate-change-telephone|title=Playing Climate-Change Telephone|work=The New Yorker|access-date=2018-05-22|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite attack on climate change scientists continues in Washington|last=Hiltzik|first=Michael|website=Los Angeles Times|date=December 4, 2015}}</ref>

{{reflist-talk}}

Please indicate your support or opposition of including the bolded text in the Lede. [[User:Marquis de Faux|Marquis de Faux]] ([[User talk:Marquis de Faux|talk]]) 02:41, 28 December 2018 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the user-generated music databases [[Rateyourmusic]], [[Discogs]], and [[Last.fm]] be added to the sourcing edit filter to strongly discourage and deprecate its use as a source on Wikipedia? [[User:Ilovetopaint|Ilovetopaint]] ([[User talk:Ilovetopaint|talk]]) 11:29, 19 January 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Turkish-backed Free Syrian Army zone#rfc_2103B42|Talk:Turkish-backed Free Syrian Army zone]] expired 2019-01-28 01:01 ===
* Id: 2103B42
* User: Jim7049
* Date: 2018-12-29 00:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|875789226|POL 875789226}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|880548945|POL 880548945}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
User [[User:Applodion|Applodion]] insists that the region know as "Northern Syrian Security belt" is a Turkish occupation zone. While in the article it is mentioned as proto state with a standing army know as TFSA ([[Turkish-backed Free Syrian Army]]), as well as President and Prime minister. This region is not a Turkish occupation zone as the Turkish army is merely present among the unrecognized proto state. Similar in the case of [[Abkhazia]], [[South Ossetia]], [[Transnistria]] and [[Donetsk People's Republic]]. All of which are small proto states under the guidance of a bigger power rather than an occupation. Similarly in the case of [[Turkish-backed Free Syrian Army zone]]. [[User:Jim7049|Jim7049]] ([[User talk:Jim7049|talk]]) 00:44, 29 December 2018 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2018 United States elections#rfc_BDE19A9|Talk:2018 United States elections]] expired 2019-01-28 07:01 ===
* Id: BDE19A9
* User: Snooganssnoogans
* Date: 2018-12-29 06:28:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|875823918|POL 875823918}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|880590889|POL 880590889}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This is a RfC on two different versions of content in the lede and body regarding whether 2018 was a blue wave election. Here are the two versions:

'''A - The "Pundits disagree whether it was a blue wave" version''':

* '''Lede:''' Pundits, journalists and political leaders differed in their assessment of the 2018 elections‚Äîsome saw the elections as a major victory for Democrats, while others argued that Democratic gains were noteworthy but modest compared to historical mid-term election results.
* '''Body:''' Analysts, journalist and pundits differed in their assessments of Democratic gains in the election.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Chinni |first1=Dante |last2=Bronston |first2=Sally |title=Was it a wave election? Depends on your data set |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/first-read/was-it-wave-election-depends-your-data-set-n939796 |accessdate=25 December 2018 |publisher=NBC News |date=25 November 2018}}</ref> It was considered a blue (Democratic) tsunami by a  Democratic strategist, Maria Cardona, and a blue wave by Republican pollster, Glen Bolger.<ref>Bolger, Glen, Cardona, Maria. "The Midterms: What did they mean? Where are we headed?" 20th Annual American Democracy Conference. University of Virginia Center for Politics, 29 Nov 2018, Washington D.C. Panel Discussion. http://crystalball.centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/cruz-schiff-highlight-center-for-politics-20th-annual-american-democracy-conference/</ref> The editorial board of ''[[The Washington Examiner]]'' argued that Republicans had suffered smaller-than-average losses for a mid-term election and Damon Young of ''[[The Root]]'' stated his belief that the election "should have been a disaster for [the Republican Party] [...] but it wasn't". [[John Cassidy (journalist)|John Cassidy]] of ''[[The New Yorker]]'' argued that the election "represented a significant rebuke to Trump". [[James Pinkerton]] of ''[[The American Conservative]]'' wrote that the election showed that voters prefer divided control of the federal government.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Jett |first1=Jennifer |title=Right and Left React to the Midterm Results |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/08/us/politics/midterms-right-left.html |accessdate=November 11, 2018 |publisher=New York Times |date=November 8, 2018}}</ref> Tara Golshan of ''[[Vox (website)|Vox]]'' argued that the election constituted a "massive victory" for Democrats, but argued that [[gerrymandering in the United States|gerrymandering]] and voter suppression prevented larger gains for the party.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Golshan |first1=Tara |title=Why wasn‚Äôt the blue wave bigger? |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/11/7/18041006/midterm-election-results-democrat-win-house-gerrymander |accessdate=November 11, 2018 |publisher=Vox |date=November 7, 2018}}</ref> Colby Itkowitz of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' wrote that the election may have constituted a "blue wave", but added that "the massive repudiation of Trump that Democrats hoped for simply didn‚Äôt happen".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Itkowitz |first1=Colby |title=Democrats pinned their hopes on a ‚Äòblue wave‚Äô in the midterms. Is that what happened? |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2018/11/07/how-argue-about-whether-these-midterms-were-blue-wave/ |accessdate=November 11, 2018 |publisher=Washington Post |date=November 7, 2018}}</ref> Nathaniel Rakich of ''[[FiveThirtyEight]]'' stated that the election was "by any historical standard, a blue wave".<ref name="rakich1">{{cite news |title=Yes, It Was A Blue Wave |url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/yes-it-was-a-blue-wave/ |accessdate=November 14, 2018 |publisher=FiveThirtyEight |date=November 14, 2018}}</ref> [[Chris Cillizza]] of [[CNN]] wrote: "Was it an A+ for [the Democratic Party]? No. But it was a hell of a lot better than a C".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Cillizza |first1=Chris |title=2018 was a WAY better election for Democrats than most people seem to think |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/11/09/politics/2018-democrats-midterms/index.html |accessdate=November 11, 2018 |publisher=CNN |date=November 10, 2018}}</ref>

'''B - "It was a blue wave" version:'''

* '''Lede:''' The election was widely characterized as a [[Wave elections in the United States|"blue wave" election]].
* '''Body:''' The election was widely characterized as a "[[Wave elections in the United States|blue wave]]" election.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/198e1fcdf57c4fd9b20a16dc1e782d51|title=Once rising GOP star, Utah's Mia Love loses seat to Democrat|last=McCOMBS|first=BRADY|date=2018-11-21|website=AP NEWS|access-date=2018-12-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/11/28/politics/blue-wave-2018/index.html|title=The 2018 blue wave, in 3 charts|last=|first=|date=2018|website=CNN|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="rakich12">{{cite news|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/yes-it-was-a-blue-wave/|title=Yes, It Was A Blue Wave|date=November 14, 2018|accessdate=November 14, 2018|publisher=FiveThirtyEight}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/nov/16/the-democratic-blue-wave-was-real|title=The Democratic blue wave was real|last=Siddiqui|first=Sabrina|date=2018-11-17|work=The Guardian|access-date=2018-12-22|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/859af1fa-f3e2-11e8-ae55-df4bf40f9d0d|title=Democratic ‚Äòblue wave‚Äô in US midterms finally crests|last=|first=|date=2018|website=Financial Times|language=en-GB|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-12-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://politi.co/2FS2gYe|title=Inside the GOP's California nightmare|last=Schneider|first=Elena|website=POLITICO|language=en|access-date=2018-12-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nymag.com/intelligencer/2018/11/2018-midterms-democratic-win.html|title=The 2018 Midterms Were a Solid Democratic Win, Not a Split Decision|last=|first=|date=2018|work=NY Mag|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/11/14/667818539/it-was-a-big-blue-wave-democrats-pick-up-most-house-seats-in-a-generation|title=It Was A Big, Blue Wave: Democrats Pick Up Most House Seats In A Generation|website=NPR.org|language=en|access-date=2018-12-22}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/trumps-base-isnt-enough/|title=Trump‚Äôs Base Isn‚Äôt Enough|last=Silver|first=Nate|date=2018-11-20|website=FiveThirtyEight|language=en-US|access-date=2018-12-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/13/us/politics/midterm-results-democratic-gains.html|title=A Week After the Election, Democratic Gains Grow Stronger|last=Burns|first=Alexander|date=2018-11-13|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-12-22|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/democracy-in-america/2018/11/15/what-does-kyrsten-sinemas-historic-win-mean-for-arizona|title=What does Kyrsten Sinema‚Äôs historic win mean for Arizona?|date=2018-11-15|work=The Economist|access-date=2018-12-22|issn=0013-0613}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=b3e15970-0619-11e9-b05b-5ba227b832f6&url=L25ld3MvYXJ0aWNsZXMvMjAxOC0xMS0yOS9sb29raW5nLXRvd2FyZC0yMDIwLWRlbW9jcmF0cy1zaGlmdC1mb2N1cy1mcm9tLWhlYWx0aC1jYXJlLXRvLW11ZWxsZXI=|title=Looking Toward 2020, Democrats Shift Focus From Health Care to Mueller|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bloomberg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-12-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/utah-republican-rep-mia-love-loses-seat-to-democrat-ben-mcadams-midterms-2018/|title=AP: Utah Republican Rep. Mia Love loses seat to Democrat Ben McAdams|website=www.cbsnews.com|access-date=2018-12-22}}</ref> At the end of election night, Democratic gains in the House appeared modest and the Democratic candidates trailed in Senate races in Arizona and Montana and looked set to make a net loss of as many as four Senate seats, leading some news outlets to characterize the election as a "split decision" whereas other outlets described it as a "blue wave".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/11/07/split-decision-us-newspapers-reacted-midterm-elections/|title='Split decision': How US newspapers reacted to the midterm elections|last=Graham|first=Chris|date=2018-11-07|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-12-29|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/07/upshot/2018-midterms-blue-wave-democrats.html|title=Why Democrats‚Äô Gain Was More Impressive Than It Appears|last=Cohn|first=Nate|date=2018-11-07|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-12-29|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> However, over the next days and weeks, Democrats won several seats in the House and won the Arizona and Montana Senate elections, leading to a re-evaluation of the initial election night analyses.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-46267519|title=How US mid-terms just got worse for Trump|last=Zurcher|first=Anthony|date=2018-11-21|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-12-29|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/13/us/politics/midterm-results-democratic-gains.html|title=A Week After the Election, Democratic Gains Grow Stronger|last=Burns|first=Alexander|date=2018-11-13|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-12-29|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> One week after the election, Nathaniel Rakich of ''[[FiveThirtyEight]]'' stated that the election was "by any historical standard, a blue wave".<ref name="rakich12" /> Two weeks after the election, Nate Silver of ''FiveThirtyEight'' wrote, "There shouldn‚Äôt be much question about whether 2018 was a wave election. Of course it was a wave."<ref name=":7" /> It was third-largest midterm change of seats for either party in the House in the post-Watergate era,<ref name=":5" /> and the largest Democratic House gain since 1974.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-46267519|title=How US mid-terms just got worse for Trump|last=Zurcher|first=Anthony|date=2018-11-21|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-12-22|language=en-GB}}</ref> [[Gerrymandering in the United States|Gerrymandering]] and voting restrictions prevented larger gains for the Democratic Party.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/11/29/us/politics/north-carolina-gerrymandering.html,%20https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/11/29/us/politics/north-carolina-gerrymandering.html|title=What‚Äôs Stronger Than a Blue Wave? Gerrymandered Districts|last=Astor|first=Maggie|date=2018-11-29|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-12-22|last2=Lai|first2=K. K. Rebecca|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/2018/11/7/18041006/midterm-election-results-democrat-win-house-gerrymander|title=Why wasn‚Äôt the blue wave bigger?|last1=Golshan|first1=Tara|date=November 7, 2018|accessdate=November 11, 2018|publisher=Vox}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-gerrymander-house-election-20181120-story.html|title=Democrats could have done even better in the midterms if it weren't for gerrymandering|last=Savage|first=David G.|website=latimes.com|access-date=2018-12-22}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=a21c8d40-0619-11e9-8220-4d0dc3368cdd&url=L2dyYXBoaWNzLzIwMTgtaG91c2Utc2VhdHMtdnMtdm90ZXMv|title=Bloomberg - Are you a robot?|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-12-22}}</ref> In two of the most heavily gerrymandered states, Ohio and North Carolina, Democrats failed to pick up a single seat, despite winning close to half the vote. Despite almost winning half the vote in Ohio, Democrats only controlled a quarter of House seats in Ohio.<ref name=":6" /> Democrats made among the largest gains in House seats in Pennsylvania where the state Supreme Court had struck down a heavily gerrymandered map that favored Republicans.<ref name=":4" /> 

{{reflist-talk}}

Please indicate whether you support '''version A''', '''version B''', neither, or some combination of both versions, along with your reasoning. [[User:Snooganssnoogans|Snooganssnoogans]] ([[User talk:Snooganssnoogans|talk]]) 06:28, 29 December 2018 (UTC)}}

"Vazken Davidian terms the expanded use of "Anatolia" to apply to territory formerly referred to as Armenia as "an historical imposition", and notes that a growing body of literature is uncomfortable with referring to the Ottoman East as "Eastern Anatolia".

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should mention of the ''Federation Generation'' terminology and the references for this terminology be deleted from this article? This includes removing "Federation Generation" from the sentence in the lead which lists other names for the demographic cohort and also deleting this paragraph from the body of the article:

{{tq|"McCrindle Research expanded on Howe's work and uses the term ''Federation Generation'' to describe [[Australians|Australian]] members of this cohort, born between 1901‚Äì1924, "a time of peace when Australia finally secured nationhood" who came of age during The [[Great Depression]] and WWII and experienced post-war prosperity in midlife."<ref>[http://mccrindle.com.au/resources/whitepapers/McCrindle-Research_ABC-01_Generations-Defined_Mark-McCrindle.pdf Generations Defined]. Mark McCrindle {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160616232732/http://mccrindle.com.au/resources/whitepapers/McCrindle-Research_ABC-01_Generations-Defined_Mark-McCrindle.pdf |date=2016-06-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=McCrindle|first1=Mark|title=The ABC of XYZ Understanding the Global Generations|url=http://www.saspa.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/The-ABC-of-XYZ_Chapter-1.pdf|accessdate=25 May 2018|publisher=McCrindle Research}}</ref>}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Name pages#rfc_DFD3C2A|Wikipedia talk:Name pages]] expired 2019-01-29 06:01 ===
* Id: DFD3C2A
* User: Coastside
* Date: 2019-01-24 08:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|880003632|PROP 880003632}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|880744812|PROP 880744812}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 This is a request for comment on a proposed guideline for handling name pages.  This guideline applies existing policy and accepted practice in a referenceable way.  It is needed because these policies are often confused, similar questions are raised repeatedly, and policies are misapplied.  In particular there is need to differentiate between name index articles and disambiguation pages. This is a guideline and does not introduce new policy.  It is a how-to guide for existing policy and accepted community standards with examples. [[User:Coastside|Coastside]] ([[User talk:Coastside|talk]]) 08:40, 24 January 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Mitch McConnell#rfc_D7CD855|Talk:Mitch McConnell]] expired 2019-02-04 18:01 ===
* Id: D7CD855
* User: Snooganssnoogans
* Date: 2019-01-05 17:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|876966807|POL 876966807}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|881767407|POL 881767407}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following text in bold be in the lede to this article (''note that the references are already in the body and would not be added to the lede''):

* McConnell was known as a pragmatist and moderate Republican early in his political career but veered sharply to the right over time. During his time in the Senate, McConnell gained a reputation as a skilled political strategist and tactician. McConnell led opposition to stricter campaign finance laws, culminating in the Supreme Court ruling that partially overturned the [[Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act|Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act (McCain-Feingold)]]. During the Obama presidency, McConnell '''engaged in obstruction''',<ref name=":8">{{Cite book|title=The Senate Syndrome: The Evolution of Procedural Warfare in the Modern U.S. Senate|last=Smith|first=Steven|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|year=2014|isbn=|location=|pages=287}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Rockman|first=Bert A.|date=October 10, 2012|title=The Obama Presidency: Hope, Change, and Reality|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1540-6237.2012.00921.x|journal=Social Science Quarterly|language=en|volume=93|issue=5|pages=1065‚Äì1080|doi=10.1111/j.1540-6237.2012.00921.x|issn=0038-4941}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/D/bo27316263.html|title=Democracy in America?|last=Page|first=Benjamin|last2=Gilens|first2=Martin|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=2018|isbn=|location=|pages=158}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Skocpol|first=Theda|last2=Jacobs|first2=Lawrence R.|date=2012|title=Accomplished and Embattled: Understanding Obama's Presidency|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/j.1538-165X.2012.tb00718.x|journal=Political Science Quarterly|language=en|volume=127|issue=1|pages=1‚Äì24|doi=10.1002/j.1538-165x.2012.tb00718.x|issn=0032-3195|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Slotnick|first=Elliot|last2=Schiavoni|first2=Sara|last3=Goldman|first3=Sheldon|date=2017|title=Obama's Judicial Legacy: The Final J.|date=2018|title=Political Trust and Polarization|url=http://www.oxfordhandbooks.com/view/10.1093/oxfordhb/9780190274801.001.0001/oxfordhb-9780190274801-e-15|journal=|language=en|publisher=Oxford Polarization in America: The war over two social contracts|last=Wood|first=B. Edition|last=Koger|first=Gregory|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=2016|isbn=|location=|pages=223|language=en-us}}</ref><ref name=":15">{{Cite name=":6">{{Cite book|url=https://global.oup.com/academic/product/health-care-reform-and-american-politics-9780190262044?cc=is&lang=en&|title=Health Care Reform and American Politics: What Everyone Needs to Know|last=Jacobs|first=Lawrence|last2=Skocpol|first2=Theda|date=2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780190262044|edition=Third|series=|location=Oxford, New York|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://press.princeton.edu/titles/11266.html|title=The Presidency of Barack Obama|last=Zelizer|first=Julian|date=2018|website=Princeton University
