=== [[Talk:List of longest-reigning monarchs#rfc_EF9CA6D|Talk:List of longest-reigning monarchs]] expired 2019-10-16 21:01 ===
* Id: EF9CA6D
* User: 62.248.181.187
* Date: 2019-10-15 14:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|921447912|HIST 921447912}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|921447921|POL 921447921}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|921625542|HIST 921625542}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|921625547|POL 921625547}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hirohito was officially subordinate to the [[Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers]] from the [[surrender of Japan]] on 2 September 1945 until the [[Treaty of San Francisco]] came into effect on 28 April 1952. The allies had official sovereignty over the former japanese territory ("occupied Japan") for that period. Furthermore, *as already discussed* it's clear that Hirohito was not a "sovereign monarch" by the 1947 constitution, and perhaps not officially a head of state at all.

Therefore I propose moving Hirohito to the second list of those who were "'''not fully sovereign over their territory for at least part of their reign'''" and adding an appropriate mention about the occupation to the note.

If disagreeing, please explain how Hirohito was a "sovereign monarch" "fully sovereign over their territory" after 2 September 1945 all the way to 1989.

[[Special:Contributions/62.248.181.187|62.248.181.187]] ([[User talk:62.248.181.187|talk]]) 14:57, 15 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Wikipedia as a press source#rfc_E796803|Wikipedia talk:Wikipedia as a press source]] expired 2019-10-18 14:01 ===
* Id: E796803
* User: Biogeographist
* Date: 2019-10-02 16:24:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|919264944|POLICY 919264944}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|919264947|PROP 919264947}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|921879514|POLICY 921879514}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|921879516|PROP 921879516}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should {{tl|Historical}} be added to [[Wikipedia:Wikipedia as a press source]] and to related Wikipedia as a press source YEAR pages listed in {{tl|PressSourceYYYY}}? Information that used to be listed on these pages is now listed in {{tl|Press}} on article talk pages, and no listings have been added for 2019 at [[Wikipedia:Wikipedia as a press source 2019]], so this series of pages appears dead/unmaintained. Note that in contrast, [[Wikipedia:Press coverage]] and related Press coverage YEAR pages listed in {{tl|PressCoverageYYYY}}, for press coverage of Wikipedia as a project (rather than of individual Wikipedia articles), is actively maintained. [[User:Biogeographist|Biogeographist]] ([[User talk:Biogeographist|talk]]) 16:24, 2 October 2019 (UTC)}}

Should the following paragraph be included in the article:
In [[Ireland]], the Control of Economic Activity (Occupied Territories) [https://data.oireachtas.ie/ie/oireachtas/bill/2018/6/eng/initiated/b0618s.pdf Bill] cleared the [[Seanad √âireann|Upper house]] on 5 December 2018 and has progressed to [https://www.oireachtas.ie/en/bills/bill/2018/6/ Third Stage][https://www.gov.ie/en/organisation-information/aba13f-bills-on-dail-order-paper/ Committee] in the [[D√°il √âireann|Lower house]] following a Second Stage vote of 78 to 45 on 24 January 2019.[https://www.irishpost.com/news/occupied-territories-bill-passes-dail-despite-government-opposition-163797 Ref][https://www.francesblack.ie/single-post/OTBillJuly2019 Ref]. (References are shown as links, the suggested section is where the current version of this material is presently located).

Enter '''Yes''' or '''No''' with one-sentence explanations in the Survey.  Back-and-forth discussion may be in Threaded Discussion.

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Islam#rfc_B4789F0|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Islam]] expired 2019-10-18 21:01 ===
* Id: B4789F0
* User: WhisperToMe
* Date: 2019-09-18 20:21:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|916424684|POL 916424684}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|916424686|RELI 916424686}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|921935624|POL 921935624}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|921935628|RELI 921935628}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The question is which languages should be included in topics related to Islamic law and Islamic concepts, particularly in regards to literature about Islamic systems or Islamic-inspired systems in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

Should the articles:
* Only include Arabic names for terminologies and not include any other languages
* Also include names of terms in Ottoman Turkish, of the Ottoman Empire, which held Mecca until around World War I
* Include names in other languages commonly used in the Islamic world

Arguments in favor of only having Arabic: Wikipedia is NOT a dictionary, and the topic is not related to any particular country.

Arguments in favor of having other languages: The information would help users understand older English documents (circa late 1800s/early 1910s) using Turkish words (instead of Arabic ones), and that Wikipedia articles like [[qi]] already display terminologies of other languages.

[[User:WhisperToMe|WhisperToMe]] ([[User talk:WhisperToMe|talk]]) 20:21, 18 September 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Idles (band)#rfc_1214A29|Talk:Idles (band)]] expired 2019-10-21 18:01 ===
* Id: 1214A29
* User: Llemiles
* Date: 2019-09-21 17:48:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|916982761|MEDIA 916982761}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|929044878|MEDIA 929044878}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hi all. Pinging {{reply to|Dekai Averett}} {{reply to|64.57.49.68}} {{reply to|Mashaunix}}, all who have discussed this issue previously.

Idles clearly describe themselves as *not* a punk band. However many third parties would indeed label their music as such. I'm quite tired of seeing edits to this page back and forth between the two perspectives.

Can we please discuss and agree what the media consensus says their 'genre' is for the infobox?

I'd like to avoid further rollback wars between editors, so for now I'll leave the band as 'Punk rock' as per the most recent settled edit, and leave a warning to all users in the code - it is best to discuss the article here rather than getting into further edit disputes.

Please vote below whether
* Yes - stating what you think the consensus for their genre is, based on media sources
* No you think the band's interpretation should be used

Thanks in anticipation. [[User:Llemiles|Llemiles]] ([[User talk:Llemiles|talk]]) 17:48, 21 September 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Robert Walker (actor, born 1918)#rfc_75F7EE7|Talk:Robert Walker (actor, born 1918)]] expired 2019-10-22 08:01 ===
* Id: 75F7EE7
* User: Coretheapple
* Date: 2019-09-30 16:21:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|918864523|BIO 918864523}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|918864526|STYLE 918864526}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|920978983|MEDIA 920978983}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|922460200|BIO 922460200}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|922460202|MEDIA 922460202}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|922460205|STYLE 922460205}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Currently the article title is [[Robert Walker (actor born 1918)]].  There are two other actors named Robert Walker, his son Robert Walker Jr., for whom the title is currently [[Robert Walker (actor, born 1940)]] and an unrelated person born in 1888, with an article name [[Robert Walker (actor, born 1888)]]. The question is whether this should be changed.

* '''Allternative A''' Leave as is.

* '''Alternative B''' Make the title of this article [[Robert Walker (actor)]] and keep the other two the same 

* '''Alternative C''' Make the title of this article [[Robert Walker (actor)]], retitle the article on the  son as [[Robert Walker Jr.]], and leave the other one the same..
-----[[User:Coretheapple|Coretheapple]] ([[User talk:Coretheapple|talk]]) 16:21, 30 September 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject UK geography/How to write about rivers#rfc_A6EB3EB|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject UK geography/How to write about rivers]] expired 2019-10-22 21:01 ===
* Id: A6EB3EB
* User: Tk420
* Date: 2019-09-22 20:04:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|917223017|HIST 917223017}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|922552564|HIST 922552564}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I would like to suggest including three more examples of local names for watercourses (X Brook, Afon X and Nant X). 'Brook' is a common name for a stream in the West Midlands which does appear in Ordnance Survey maps of the area e.g. [[Rea Brook]] in Shropshire. As for 'Afon' and 'Nant' they are the Welsh words for 'river' and 'stream' respectively and are also used in OS maps of Wales often without an English equivalent. I decided to start this discussion after noticing some articles about rivers in Wales use the Welsh prefix 'Afon' in their titles particularly for the smaller lesser-known rivers e.g. [[Afon Rheidol]] and [[Afon Dulas]] although this is the English-language Wikipedia. I am however unsure of the formality, as opposed to colloquialism, of the use of 'afon' in English. The most formal example of the 'Afon' prefix in English I have found is in a video from Natural Resources Wales in the [[River Dyfi]] article. I had started discussions on moving the [[Afon Twymyn]] and [[Afon Rheidol]] articles but both times it was decided not to move those articles and the opponents of the proposals argue that the use of 'Afon X' is normal locally. The article [[Welsh English]] describes at least four dialects of English within Wales (North Wales, Cardiff, South Wales Valleys and West Wales). According to the [[Anglicisation]] article the preference for Welsh place names over similar-sounding anglicisations is more common in the west of Wales so the same might be true for the 'Afon' prefix. As for 'Nant X' I have seen it used in OS maps and on local signs for streams in Wales e.g. Nant Gwernol, [[Nant Br√¢n]] and [[Nant Ceiswyn]] without an English name of any kind. [[User:Tk420|Tk420]] ([[User talk:Tk420|talk]]) 20:04, 22 September 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Tim Pool#rfc_BD63E5E|Talk:Tim Pool]] expired 2019-10-22 21:01 ===
* Id: BD63E5E
* Date: 2019-10-22 18:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|922535791|UNSORTED 922535791}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|922552580|UNSORTED 922552580}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Please correct my formatting if needed

Certain sources [https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/social-media/conspiracy-theorists-far-right-agitators-head-white-house-social-media-n1028576 1] [https://www.thedailybeast.com/trump-praises-right-wing-conspiracy-theorists-at-white-house-the-crap-you-think-of-is-unbelievable 2] [https://deadline.com/2019/07/donald-trump-social-media-summit-elizabeth-warren-stable-genius-1202644883/ 3] [https://newrepublic.com/article/154467/trump-social-media-summit-assembles-gang-deplorables 4] mention Tim Pool as a conspiracy theorist, either in passing or as part of a list of others.  At least one source also includes a refutation from Pool, stating that he did not promote the conspiracy theory, although he did mention it and said he needed further evidence about it.  [[WP:CONTEXTMATTERS]] States that " Information provided in passing by an otherwise reliable source that is not related to the principal topics of the publication may not be reliable; editors should cite sources focused on the topic at hand where possible."  We disagree on whether these sources, while traditionally considered reliable by WP, are reliable in this case, as I think we ''would'' agree here that common sense shows Pool did not actually promote the theory as really true.  We also disagree on how notable for inclusion the sources are relative to Pool's biography.  And we would like clarification as to whether it is appropriate per the special protections in [[WP:BLP]] to include accusations which are mentioned by the sources in passing and have been denied by the subject.  We are also in need of clarification as to whether ''if'' we include a sentence stating that Pool has been accused of promoting a conspiracy theory, whether we should also state that he denies the charge (per one of the secondary sources and his own statements). [[User_talk:Becritical|<span style="color:black;">'''B'''<sup>e</sup> <span style="font-size: 20px;>‚ä¢</span> '''C'''<sup>ritical</sup></span>]] 18:43, 22 October 2019 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Should we include:
# All awardees regardless of notability and sourcing
# All awardees for which a reliable independent secondary source (i.e. not a press release) can be found 
# Only notable awardees (i.e. with articles)
# None of the above
The above RfC last year did not address sourcing, and many of those expressing a view did not seem to understand that [[WP:RS]] is policy. <b>[[user:JzG|Guy]]</b> <small>([[user talk:JzG|help!]])</small> 20:41, 23 September 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Psalms#rfc_FC0A4D0|Talk:Psalms]] expired 2019-10-25 23:01 ===
* Id: FC0A4D0

=== [[Talk:Singapore#rfc_3B227E9|Talk:Singapore]] expired 2019-10-26 07:01 ===
* Id: 3B227E9
* User: Zubin12
* Date: 2019-09-26 06:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|918776360|HIST 918776360}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|923080844|HIST 923080844}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Should the following paragraph be included in this articles lead ?'''

"Singapore is a global hub for education,[9] finance, healthcare,[10] innovation,[11] manufacturing,[12] technology,[13] tourism,[14] trade, and transport.[15] The city-state does well in international rankings, including: the most "technology-ready" nation (WEF), most competitive economy (IMD),[16][17] top International-meetings city (UIA),[18][19] city with "best investment potential" (BERI), Smart City,[20] Safest country,[21][22] third least-corrupt country, third-largest foreign exchange market, third-largest financial centre, third-largest oil refining and trading centre, fifth-most innovative country, and the second-busiest container port.[23] The city-state is classified as an Alpha+ global city, indicating its influence on the global economy. Singapore is the only country in Asia with an AAA sovereign rating from all major rating agencies, and one of 11 worldwide. Globally, the Port of Singapore and Changi Airport have held the titles of leading "Maritime Capital" and "Best Airport" respectively for consecutive years, while Singapore Airlines is the 2018 "World's Best Airline".[24][25] "
[[User:Zubin12|Zubin12]] ([[User talk:Zubin12|talk]]) 06:55, 26 September 2019 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:Redirect#rfc_5A84324|Wikipedia talk:Redirect]] expired 2019-10-26 12:01 ===
* Id: 5A84324
* Date: 2019-09-26 11:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|917980033|POLICY 917980033}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|923106855|POLICY 923106855}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Is it disruptive or beneficial to introduce redirects into articles, i.e. to replace pipes with redirects? E.g. is it beneficial or disruptive to replace <nowiki> [[Season (sports)#Off-season|off-season]] with [[off-season]], [[Defender (association football)|centre-half]] with [[centre-half]]</nowiki>, etc? More examples can be found [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kevin_Beattie&type=revision&diff=916311999&oldid=916221354 here]. After the RfC is concluded, this should ideally be clarified in the guideline itself. 11:40, 26 September 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Dendrochytridium#rfc_5AC8C28|Talk:Dendrochytridium]] expired 2019-10-28 01:01 ===
* Id: 5AC8C28
* User: TelosCricket
* Date: 2019-09-28 00:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|918304645|SCI 918304645}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|918304649|PROJ 918304649}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|923354829|SCI 923354829}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|923354830|PROJ 923354830}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
How should the etymology of the genus be presented? ([[Dendrochytridium]]) The source states '''Etymology: Greek; ''dendro'' = tree, in recognition of the origin of the type isolate; chytridium recognizes the type genus of the order.''' The problem is that this is not correct according to classical Greek, and there is disagreement about how the etymology should be presented. [[User:TelosCricket|TelosCricket]] ([[User talk:TelosCricket|talk]]) 00:38, 28 September 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Cultural impact of the Beatles#rfc_6001886|Talk:Cultural impact of the Beatles]] expired 2019-10-29 09:01 ===
* Id: 6001886
* User: ILIL
* Date: 2019-09-29 08:40:00

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The article currently states that in late 1966, the Beatles became the first "entertainment act" in history to give up concert touring in order to focus on studio-recorded efforts. However, it is widely known that [[Brian Wilson]] of the Beach Boys made the same career decision more than a year earlier. Should the article thus remove this credit to the Beatles? --[[User:ILIL|ilil]] ([[User talk:ILIL|talk]]) 08:40, 29 September 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Results of the 2019 Canadian federal election#rfc_A7EAEB3|Talk:Results of the 2019 Canadian federal election]] expired 2019-10-30 00:01 ===
* Id: A7EAEB3
* User: MikkelJSmith
* Date: 2019-10-29 15:04:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|923601987|POL 923601987}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|923662721|POL 923662721}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
So, after looking at this page, I see that some of the prose on here is identical to the prose on the 2019 Canadian federal election page. The prose was added there by consensus when we wanted to put that page in the ''In the News'' section of Wikipedia. I'm also planning on adding an analysis section and election aftermath section to the [[2019 Canadian federal election]] page. In fact, some of the prose in the results section can fit in the former. And the latter needs to be added due to some ramifications the election has had already. We've also had an election aftermath section in previous elections, so that will probably need to be added anyways.

To continue, I was looking at other elections for other countries like the [[2017 United Kingdom general election|UK 2017 general election]] and I saw that it separated prose and and tables. However, in the past for Canadian elections the prose was in a separate article like this one (the Results page). But, that doesn't seem practical to me. So, I was wondering if we should separate the prose and the tables. The prose/analysis should be on the 2019 Canadian election page since we already reached consensus that there should be prose there and the tables should be on this page. If we don't solve it, we'll have two repetitive pages. A preview of what I am proposing can be seen when we look at the UK pages : [[Results_breakdown_of_the_2017_United_Kingdom_general_election]]
[[Results_of_the_2017_United_Kingdom_general_election]] 
''Edit: I need to add that I'm in favor of keeping simple tables on the main page but moving the more detailed stuff here. ''

It's a question of consistency vs practicality. Although, if we do the changes that I propose, we can simply go back to previous Canadian elections and make the changes there as well. -- [[User:MikkelJSmith|MikkelJSmith]] ([[User talk:MikkelJSmith|talk]]) 15:04, 29 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Requests for permissions#rfc_D9D4AAA|Wikipedia talk:Requests for permissions]] expired 2019-11-03 03:01 ===
* Id: D9D4AAA
* Date: 2019-10-04 03:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|919514666|PROP 919514666}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|924316792|PROP 924316792}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There has been a lot of discussion about whether AfC and NPP rights should be merged or kept separate. This RfC is an attempt to gauge the community consensus on the relationship between these rights. What should the relationship between [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Articles for creation/Participants|permissions for Articles for Creation]] and [[Wikipedia:Requests for permissions/New page reviewer|New Page Patroller]] be?
*'''Option 1''' Merge these two rights - the work is similar and share an interface, so editors should have similar experience and capabilities. Someone with one right should be fully capable of performing the tasks of the other right. The details of how this merge would happen should be worked out in subsequent discussion.
*'''Option 2''' Keep separate - Because AfC reviews are routinely checked by new page patrollers, AfC may be granted to editors who are missing some experience or capability expected of new page patrollers 
*'''Option 3''' Keep separate - The experience and capabilities needed for each right are different and so the permissions are not comparable 
[[User:Barkeep49|Barkeep49]] ([[User_talk:Barkeep49|talk]]) 03:01, 4 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion#rfc_7A49EA1|Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion]] expired 2019-11-03 04:01 ===
* Id: 7A49EA1
* Date: 2019-10-23 15:04:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|922672996|POLICY 922672996}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|922672999|PROP 922672999}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|924323216|POLICY 924323216}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|924323217|PROP 924323217}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
So, I thought that it might be possible to simplify the CSD criteria, and make it easier for new users to grasp them. So, I am proposing a rewrite of the CSD criteria. Here's a list of the changes I am proposing:

''' Proposed changes '''

''' Merges into new criteria '''

* G1, A1 ‚Üí G15 - Pages lacking a clear subject
* F1, A10, T3 ‚Üí G16 - Redundant
* A3, F2, C1, G14 ‚Üí G17 - No content

''' Merges into already existing criteria '''

* F9 - Unambiguous copyright infringement ‚Üí G12 - Unambiguous copyright infringement
* U1 - User Request ‚Üí G7 - Author requests deletion

I believe these changes will make the criteria easier for new users to learn, allowing them to use the criteria better. <span style="font-family:monospace;font-size:14px;">[[User:InvalidOS|<span style="color:#06A;">Invalid</span>]]<sup>[[User:InvalidOS/c|<span style="color:#A60">OS</span>]]</sup> ([[User:InvalidOS/t|talk]])</span> 15:04, 23 October 2019 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
 to this talk page to solicit additional, objective expert opinions about the authority of western academics to assess the authenticity of Buddhist teachings, and to say who can or cannot represent Buddhist teachings. 
In the meantime I deleted this section, as no counter-argument has been presented. (It does not make sense to retitle this section 'Departure from Traditional Buddhism' in my opinion, since he teaches only the ngondro of the 9th Karmapa, and Mahamudra teachings from Tilopa, the third Karmapa and Lama Zhang. These are all very traditional teachings. I see no evidence to indicate teachings that are in any way a departure from traditional Karma Kagyu Buddhism.
In future, please use the talk page before making so many drastic edits to a controversial page. 

[[User:Mekinna1|Mekinna1]] ([[User talk:Mekinna1|talk]]) 04:41, 4 November 2019 (UTC)}}

 There is a debate about whether announcements of future vehicles is worthwhile to put on WP or not.

This RFC is asking:
#Should announcements by company representatives for near future vehicles be reported on WP?<br>How about for magazine speculation?

#How much should we highlight the changeable nature of the forecast?
#Does [[WP:CRYSTALBALL]] apply to sections within articles? See clauses 1 and 5.
This discussion is meant to apply to the automobile project as a whole, not just to this M3 discussion that started it.<span style="border:1px solid blue;border-radius:4px;color:blue;box-shadow: 3px 3px 4px grey;">[[User:Stepho-wrs|'''&nbsp;Stepho&nbsp;''']]&nbsp;<span style="font-size:xx-small; vertical-align:top">[[User Talk:Stepho-wrs|talk]]&nbsp;</span></span> 00:42, 6 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Requests for comment/2019 Resysop Criteria (2)#rfc_B0CA403|Wikipedia:Requests for comment/2019 Resysop Criteria (2)]] expired 2019-11-05 01:01 ===
* Id: B0CA403
* User: TonyBallioni
* Date: 2019-10-06 00:18:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|919819761|POLICY 919819761}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|924633116|POLICY 924633116}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In October 2019 the first part of a two part Request for Comment was [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia_talk%3AAdministrators&type=revision&diff=919786962&oldid=916134048#Resysop_criteria:_RfC_on_principles closed] with a community consensus in favour of developing a stricter criteria for restoration of administrator status after a desysop for inactivity. 

The first RfC stipulated that if it closed with a consensus for a stricter criteria there would be a second RfC. This RfC will follow the endorsement of statements model, with users being able to put forward multiple proposals to be considered by the community. [[User:TonyBallioni|TonyBallioni]] ([[User talk:TonyBallioni|talk]]) 00:18, 6 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion#rfc_6206058|Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion]] expired 2019-11-07 03:01 ===
* Id: 6206058
* User: Hasteur
* Date: 2019-10-08 02:49:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|920182636|POLICY 920182636}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|924984162|POLICY 924984162}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have observed that several administrators have started treating pages that have been nominated or deleted under CSD:G13 (Stale Drafts and submissions) to be summarily restored citing a finding that because the last XfD was a Keep (or no consensus) CSD:G13 is invalid on the page until a XfD results in a delete.  I therefore propose the following modification to CSD:G13 to establish if there is a consensus for that interpretation.

Any pages that have not been edited by a human in six months found in: 
# [[WP:Drafts|Draft namespace]],
# [[WP:UD|Userspace]] with an {{Tl|AFC submission}} template
# Userspace with no content except the [[Wikipedia:Article Wizard|article wizard]] placeholder text. 
Redirects are exempt from G13 deletion. '''Pages that have survived their most recent [[WP:XFD|deletion attempt]] are exempt from G13 deletion.''' Pages deleted under G13 may be restored upon request by following the procedure at [[Wikipedia:Requests for undeletion/G13]]. [[User:Hasteur|Hasteur]] ([[User talk:Hasteur|talk]]) 02:49, 8 October 2019 (UTC)}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|920379392|LANG 920379392}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|920379395|STYLE 920379395}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|920379399|POLICY 920379399}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|925187357|LANG 925187357}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|925187358|STYLE 925187358}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|925187359|POLICY 925187359}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Request for comment as to whether "{{strong|I}}nternet" should be upper or lower case, and whether this is suitable for inclusion in [[WP:MOS/CAPS]]. Please see this [[wikipedia_talk:Manual of Style/Capital letters#Capitalisation of internet vs Internet|previous discussion]]. 
Recognising that the "{{strong|I}}nternet" used to be, or still is a proper name, upper case {{strong|I}}nternet remains American English (with its usage  decreasing in American English). In other national varieties of English, {{strong|i}}nternet is much more common. [[Capitalization of Internet#Argument for proper noun usage|In the relevant article, we are unable to find a source for it being a proper name]]. "Internet" doesn't fall into any of the capitalization categories discussed in MOS, and I think it warrants specific mention, as there are numerous examples I have run across, where it causes reverts or confusion. Numerous external style guides mention this specifically. --'''<span style="font-size:90%;font-family:courier">[[User:E.3|<span style="color:#DB2E16">[E.3]</span>]][[User talk:E.3|<span style="color:#FF9933">[chat2]</span>]][[Special:Contributions/E.3|<span style="color:#FF7133">[me]</span>]]</span>''' 11:58, 9 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Bell Media Radio#rfc_6C1AE3D|Talk:Bell Media Radio]] expired 2019-11-08 16:01 ===
* Id: 6C1AE3D
* User: Dmehus
* Date: 2019-10-09 15:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|920406597|MEDIA 920406597}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|925212505|MEDIA 925212505}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
With the disputed page move to [[IHeartRadio Canada]] now reverted and out of the way, I will say that [[User:ViperSnake151]] raised an interesting point of the separate IHeartRadio streaming radio network affiliation. Looking at [[Template:Infobox radio station]], it seems like the '''Network''' parameter is for branding to which a group of stations belong (i.e., Virgin Radio). Could it also be used for a streaming radio network, or would '''Affiliation''' be better? I'm going to ping {{ping|Bearcat}} for his expertise on the matter and also issue an RfC to generate a discussion. I'm wondering if this could be a worthwhile project to add such a parameter to the [[Bell Media Radio]] station infoboxes? Also, separately, the parameter usage documentation is quite scant, so I'm not quite such what attributes can be used with each parameter (specifically, the two mentioned). Should we initiate a separate RfC on that template's Talk page?

'''Note:''' When this RfC is closed, please ensure it's closed by adding the proper beginning, end, and result tags to this RfC. Thanks. [[User:Dmehus|Doug Mehus]] ([[User talk:Dmehus|talk]]) 15:43, 9 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:The Bible and homosexuality#rfc_3C5FA19|Talk:The Bible and homosexuality]] expired 2019-11-09 15:01 ===
* Id: 3C5FA19
* Date: 2019-10-10 14:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|920559890|RELI 920559890}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|925349143|RELI 925349143}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This rfc is being opened to attract more discussion on the following subject and to gain consensus one way or the other:

The second sentence in the article currently reads:

<i>"These two verses have historically been interpreted by Jews and Christians as clear overall prohibitions against homosexual acts in general."</i>

I propose to insert word "Traditionalist" so that the sentence reads:

<i>"These two verses have historically been interpreted by <b>Traditionalist</b> Jews and Christians as clear overall prohibitions against homosexual acts in general."</i>

I propose to make this change because:

'''1.)''' Since not all Christians support this interpretation, it would make the wording more accurate, as the current wording, IMHO makes it look like ''all'' Christians support that interpretation. 

'''2.)''' There is no source being used to support the current sentence as it stands.

I have attempted to add the word "Traditionalist" once,  Roscelese doesn't support this and has removed it, as is her right.   We started a discussion, and so far it's been only her and I.  So I now welcome more eyes and hands to this discussion.   What do you think ? [[User:Wekeepwhatwekill|<span style="text-shadow:grey 0.2em 0.2em 0.4em">'''Necromonger...'''</span>]][[User_talk:Wekeepwhatwekill|<span style=";text-shadow:Grey 0.2em 0.2em 0.4em;">''We keep what we kill'']]</span> 14:33, 10 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Did you know#rfc_3F6D3A1|Wikipedia talk:Did you know]] expired 2019-11-11 02:01 ===
* Id: 3F6D3A1
* User: Taewangkorea
* Date: 2019-10-29 20:47:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|923640168|POLICY 923640168}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|925589126|POLICY 925589126}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Over the past 1.5 months or so reviewers at DYK have raised concerns regarding currently available commercial products going on the front page as a DYK (newly-released smartphones in particular). They have thought that such newly-released smartphones may act as a form of advertising. Thus, after [[Wikipedia talk:Did you know#Queue 2%3A Samsung Galaxy M30s|several]] [[Wikipedia talk:Did you know/Archive 162#Concerns about promotional content|discussions]] that failed to gain meaningful progress, I am holding this RfC to get the opinions of other editors on the suitability of the inclusion of currently available commercial products at DYK. [[User:Taewangkorea|Taewangkorea]] ([[User talk:Taewangkorea|talk]]) 20:47, 29 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Emilia Clarke#rfc_B480B16|Talk:Emilia Clarke]] expired 2019-11-12 03:01 ===
* Id: B480B16
* User: 24.217.247.41
* Date: 2019-10-13 02:21:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|921217494|BIO 921217494}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|921226379|MEDIA 921226379}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|925753955|BIO 925753955}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Currently, [[Emilia Clarke]]'s wikipedia page does not include the fact that she dated [[Seth MacFarlane]] from 2012 to 2013, despite the fact that it is currently included on his wikipedia page, multiple RS have reported on the relationship [https://www.huffpost.com/entry/seth-macfarlane-splits-emilia-clarke_n_2922787][https://www.eonline.com/news/754072/emilia-clarke-finally-opens-up-about-dating-seth-macfarlane][https://www.eonline.com/news/399162/seth-macfarlane-splits-from-game-of-thrones-girlfriend-emilia-clarke], and [https://www.glamour.com/story/emilia-clarke-cover-interview Clarke did an interview with Glamour Magazine in which she directly confirmed the relationship] and commented on being disappointed in negative fan reactions to her dating him. Should [[Emilia Clarke]]'s article include at least 1 sentence, similar to that of [[Seth MacFarlane]]'s stating that they briefly dated from 2012-2013? 

* '''Yes''', include one sentence stating that " "Clarke dated actor and comedian Seth MacFarlane from 2012 to 2013" [https://www.glamour.com/story/emilia-clarke-cover-interview]

* '''No''', do not include any mention of her dating Seth MacFarlane.

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style#rfc_E4B5DFF|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style]] expired 2019-11-13 01:01 ===
* Id: E4B5DFF
* User: KyleJoan
* Date: 2019-10-20 03:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|922129531|LANG 922129531}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|922129533|MEDIA 922129533}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|922129538|STYLE 922129538}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|922129539|POLICY 922129539}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|925901001|LANG 925901001}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|925901002|MEDIA 925901002}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|925901004|STYLE 925901004}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|925901008|POLICY 925901008}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This issue has to do with the sorting of surnames that are preceded by prefixes known as particles, such as ''de'' or ''von''.  The rules for sorting of surnames are complex and depend on the customs of the nationality.  The question is whether names should be sorted based on the national origin of the surname, or the nationality of the person.  An example is Luann de Lesseps, an American socialite and reality TV personality, whose surname is that of her French nobleman husband.  Should she be alphabetized as:
'''A'''.  de Lesseps, Luann (nationality of person, American)  
or
'''B'''.  Lesseps, Luann de (national origin of name, French)
or
'''C'''.  It depends.  If so, specify what it depends on.

Enter your !votes with a brief statement as '''A''' or '''B'''.  Enter any back-and-forth comments in the Threaded Discussion.

RfC expired on October 16 and restarted on October 20. [[User:KyleJoan|<span style="font-family:Consolas; color:#CD8C95">'''K'''yle'''J'''oan</span>]]<sup>[[User talk:KyleJoan|<span style="font-family:Consolas; color:#8B6969">talk</span>]]</sup>  03:17, 20 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Sharyl Attkisson#rfc_4F4FBB5|Talk:Sharyl Attkisson]] expired 2019-11-13 04:01 ===
* Id: 4F4FBB5
* User: Dmehus
* Date: 2019-11-13 02:34:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|925915236|BIO 925915236}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|925921129|BIO 925921129}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edit reversion by {{u|Toa Nidhiki05}} cannot stand because citation "Vaccine journal" contains '''no mention''' of Sharyl Attkisson. Indeed, the only mention of the reporter's name in the journal writer's article is in a blog post, which the journal writer cites. The article itself makes no mention of Ms. Attkisson. Thus, we have a [[WP:BLP]] violation. At ''minimum'', this cannot stand.

More broadly, the sourcing in this section needs to be discussed and rewritten, where appropriate, consistent with [[WP:BLP]].

Cheers,
<br />--[[User:Dmehus|'''Doug Mehus''']]''<span style="font-size:small; vertical-align:top;">  [[User talk:Dmehus|T]]</span>''¬∑''<span style="font-size:small; vertical-align:bottom;">[[Special:Contributions/Dmehus|C]]</span>'' 02:34, 13 November 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Irvin Rockman#rfc_F8D3595|Talk:Irvin Rockman]] expired 2019-11-14 15:01 ===
* Id: F8D3595
* User: ClearBreeze
* Date: 2019-10-15 14:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|921402822|BIO 921402822}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|926147897|BIO 926147897}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 
Should this article detail allegations against the late Irvin Rockman that were subject to a Parliamentary inquiry that he: (1) financed drug importation; (2) engaged in witness intimidation leading to the suicide of a woman, Cassandra Ogdon, who was due to give evidence against him; (3) that the State Coroner in his report of Ogdon's death, found that Rockman had lied at the inquest; and (4) that following this, the National Crime Authority began assembling a criminal case against him, but it never proceeded due to other circumstances. The disputed content is found in this earlier version of the article: [[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Irvin_Rockman&oldid=920683757]] The sources are the Parliamentary Report, two leading newspapers, and an investigative book. [[User:ClearBreeze|ClearBreeze]] ([[User talk:ClearBreeze|talk]]) 14:33, 15 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Verifiability#rfc_414594C|Wikipedia talk:Verifiability]] expired 2019-11-14 17:01 ===
* Id: 414594C
* User: Paul Siebert
* Date: 2019-11-13 06:51:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|925938404|POLICY 925938404}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|926167205|POLICY 926167205}}
* RFC Text:

The policy says that mainstream newspapers are reliable sources. How can we determine if some newspaper is mainstream? Should we explain the mainstreamness criteria?

Second question: are all newspapers by default considered mainstream unless the opposite is demonstrated, or ''vise versa'': those editors who add a newspaper article are expected to provide a proof that they are mainstream? 

Do policy or guidelines say anything about that, and if not, maybe we should explain that?--[[User:Paul Siebert|Paul Siebert]] ([[User talk:Paul Siebert|talk]]) 06:51, 13 November 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Responses to the 2019 Venezuelan presidential crisis#rfc_25BEB2E|Talk:Responses to the 2019 Venezuelan presidential crisis]] expired 2019-11-15 16:01 ===
* Id: 25BEB2E
* User: Kingsif
* Date: 2019-10-16 15:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|921582694|POL 921582694}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|926321544|POL 926321544}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should Venezuelan crisis-related articles use terms like 'pro-Maduro', and, if not, what alternatives can be used?
Some initial notes:
* The result of this discussion, and comments in it, may be used to make up a standing guideline for WikiProject Venezuela - to maintain consistency and abide with consensus through all related articles.
* I would suggest not using POV/NPOV arguments in regards the use of 'pro-Maduro' and similar - this is where the original cyclical debate came from, because it can be interpreted differently, and these arguments don't seem to sway anyone. Equally, of course, defending the terms as being neutral shouldn't be used an argument to keep them.
* Please keep in mind the unique situation of Venezuela; it is almost impossible to compare with any other country.
* This discussion also includes use of 'pro-Guaid√≥' and 'pro-government'.
* Please keep comments and replies coherent, using appropriate indents and third-level headers if necessary.
:[[User:Kingsif|Kingsif]] ([[User talk:Kingsif|talk]]) 15:45, 16 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Effective altruism#rfc_3A455B7|Template talk:Effective altruism]] expired 2019-11-16 03:01 ===
* Id: 3A455B7
* User: Robert McClenon
* Date: 2019-10-17 02:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|921666574|ECON 921666574}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|921666577|RELI 921666577}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|926399238|ECON 926399238}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|926399240|RELI 926399240}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|926399242|SOC 926399242}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is discussion about which scholars to include in the list of Key Figures of Effective Altruism in the {{tl|Effective altruism}} template.  The names on which there is agreement are:
* [[William MacAskill]]
* [[Toby Ord]]
* [[Holden Karnofsky]]
* <del>[[Eliezer Yudkowsky]]</del>
* [[Dustin Moskovitz]]
* [[Peter Singer]]
* [[Liv Boeree]]
* [[Hilary Greaves]]

A.  Should [[Jacy Reese]] be included in the list?

B.  Should [[Nick Bostrom]], [[Yew-Kwang Ng]], [[Derek Parfit]], and [[Eliezer Yudkowsky]] be included in the list?

Please answer Yes or No to the above questions in the appropriate sections.  Do not engage in back-and-forth discussion in the Survey.  Back-and-forth discussion is permitted in the Threaded Discussion.  (That's what it's for.)  

[[User:Robert McClenon|Robert McClenon]] ([[User talk:Robert McClenon|talk]]) 02:09, 17 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox organization#rfc_8D88F36|Template talk:Infobox organization]] expired 2019-11-16 22:01 ===
* Id: 8D88F36
* User: Wugapodes
* Date: 2019-10-17 21:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|921787823|STYLE 921787823}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|921787826|TECH 921787826}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|926510133|STYLE 926510133}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|926510135|TECH 926510135}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Per the edit requests by {{U|Goldsztajn}}, I've updated the sandbox version of this template to have two new parameters: {{para|full name}} and {{para|full name lang}}. Additionally, I have updated {{para|native name}} and {{para|native name lang}} to use {{tl|lang}} so that metadata on non-English scripts can be added. In most cases these changes should be non-breaking, but if existing transclusions use a non-ISO language code or use a language name not supported by {{tl|ISO 639 code-3}}, the template produces an error message. I believe the benefit of the metadata outweighs the harm of a few errors, but want to establish consensus before these changes are made. [[User:Wugapodes|Wug¬∑]][[User talk:Wugapodes|a¬∑po¬∑des]]‚Äã 21:55, 17 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Russia national football team#rfc_63A5033|Talk:Russia national football team]] expired 2019-11-17 05:01 ===
* Id: 63A5033
* User: Josephua
* Date: 2019-10-18 04:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|921828306|SOC 921828306}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|926555183|SOC 926555183}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
We need to start a new consensus whether we can use the Russian Football Union logo or the Russian coat of arms in the infobox. There has been too much edit instability (probably be declared edit warring if so be) revolving around the use of the logo, with editors (including me) switching the coat of arms with the logo and vice-versa, and this has been going on forever. We should acknowledge two factors, one for each side:

* In https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Files_for_discussion/2016_September_2, a consensus by the administrators declared that the logo should only be used for the [[Russian Football Union]] article and only for this instance, with this reasoning here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Files_for_discussion/2016_September_2#File:Russian_Football_Union.png.
* In the summary of File:Russia national football team crest.svg, it is allowed to be in minimal use under [[WP:NFCC#3]], and the only article for such minimal use is the Russian national football team.

There is a much needed consensus or else there will be continual edit warring between not two users but multiple. For the consensus, state '''Support''' if you want to use the logo for the infobox image or '''Oppose''' if you want the coat of arms to remain as the primary infobox image. - [[User:Josephua|Josephua]] ([[User talk:Josephua|talk]]) 04:20, 18 October 2019 (UTC)}}

There are serveal sources reported protesters‚Äô violence, but Chinese media has hardly report news which would prise the protests. The media are different in weight issues.

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Television#rfc_55BB05D|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Television]] expired 2019-11-20 21:01 ===
* Id: 55BB05D
* User: Sceptre
* Date: 2019-10-21 20:56:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|922392081|STYLE 922392081}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|933298388|STYLE 933298388}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{see also|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Television/August 2016 updates/PSE image}}

With regards to this section of MOS:TVIMAGE:

{{quote|For a show's main article, an intertitle shot of the show (i.e., a screenshot capture of the show's title) or a promotional poster used to represent the show itself should be used.}}

I propose to replace it with:

{{quote|For a show's main article, '''the show's logo''',  a promotional '''image''' used to represent the show itself, or an intertitle shot of the show (i.e., a screenshot capture of the show's title), should be used. '''In such a case where the logo is free to use, it is preferred over non-free media.'''}}

My reasons for the proposal are thus:

*This would reflect current practice: see, for example, [[The Simpsons]], [[House (TV series)]], [[Sesame Street]], all FAs which use representative free-to-use logos instead of non-free intertitles. 
*Intertitles for use in infoboxes tend to have massive image compression problems to try to find a sweet spot with regards to passing NFCC, an issue that we can side-step with a free-to-use logo. 
**If free media can be found to represent a television show just as well as the intertitle, then [[WP:NFCCP#1]] implicitly fails for the intertitle. '''[[User:Sceptre|Sceptre]]''' ([[User talk:Sceptre|talk]]) 20:56, 21 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act#rfc_4FA5F5F|Talk:Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act]] expired 2019-11-22 05:01 ===
* Id: 4FA5F5F
* User: Mariogoods
* Date: 2019-10-23 04:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|922605551|POL 922605551}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|927387699|POL 927387699}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{tq|China‚Äôs Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang responded that the bill "fully reveals the ill intentions of some people in the United States to mess up Hong Kong and contain China's development." The managing director of a Hong Kong pro-democracy group said through a statement sent to Newsweekthat the foreign ministry's response showed that the PRC was "sensitive and susceptible to international pressure."  After the House passed the Act, Beijing condemned the move and said it would take countermeasures. An article in Politico said that Jim Risch (R-ID), chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, appeared undeterred by Beijing's reaction, telling reporters that he hoped for quick Senate action on the bill. }}I have attempted to deleted the sentences presenting the analysis of Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeman‚Äôs response, but these edits got reverted. It is not because I want to hide their opinions. But I think their opinions are somewhat too detailed. I believed that Chinese will actually do something and the reactions from Chinese government will be expanded. The format now is like ‚ÄúChinese statement-analysis-Chinese statement-analysis‚Äù, which may be harmful to readlity. I have suggested serveal solutions:
*Choice 1: Giving divided sub-sections such as ‚ÄúChinese government reactions‚Äù, ‚ÄúHong Kong reactions‚Äù and deleting these analysis;
*Choice 2: Giving divided sub-sections: such as ‚ÄúChinese government reactions‚Äù, ‚ÄúHong Kong reactions‚Äù and not to delete these analysis;
*Choice 3: Delete these analysis only;
*Choice 4: Not to delete these analysis.
Any other suggestions are welcomed.
[[User:Mariogoods|Mariogoods]] ([[User talk:Mariogoods|talk]]) 04:17, 23 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of nicknames of presidents of the United States#rfc_8D0C225|Talk:List of nicknames of presidents of the United States]] expired 2019-11-22 14:01 ===
* Id: 8D0C225
* User: Objective3000
* Date: 2019-10-23 13:42:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|922656476|BIO 922656476}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|922656480|HIST 922656480}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|922656482|POL 922656482}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|933298375|BIO 933298375}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|933298380|HIST 933298380}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|933298382|POL 933298382}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What should be the scope of this article? This article has long suffered from [[WP:RECENTISM]], [[WP:POV]], and [[WP:BLP]] issues. Although most of the article is stable, the subsections on the current president and to a lesser extent the previous president are targets of nearly all edits. The vast majority of these edits are reverted as they are based on what one commentator or comedian called a president and are unlikely to stand the test of time. Should we change the scope of the article as follows:

*'''Option A''' ‚Äì Leave as is.
*'''Option B''' ‚Äì Remove the current president and move to ''List of nicknames of past presidents of the United States''.
*'''Option C''' ‚Äì Remove the current president and previous president (e.g. Trump and Obama) and move.
*'''Option D''' ‚Äì Remove modern era presidents. Please specify where to draw the line.
[[User:Objective3000|O3000]] ([[User talk:Objective3000|talk]]) 13:42, 23 October 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_E3CADB8|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2019-11-22 15:01 ===
* Id: E3CADB8
* Date: 2019-10-23 14:27:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|922664283|POL 922664283}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|927441083|POL 927441083}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
We have many stand-alone and embedded lists of political campaign endorsements (see for example, [[:Category:2020 United States presidential election endorsements]]). The inclusion criteria of these lists are frequently debated, and the lists themselves subject to frequent additions based on unclear language published only on social media. This RfC attempts to create baseline inclusion criteria for such lists, which can be built upon as needed on article talk pages. &mdash; <samp>[[User:Rhododendrites|<span style="font-size:90%;letter-spacing:1px;text-shadow:0px -1px 0px Indigo;">Rhododendrites</span>]] <sup style="font-size:80%;">[[User_talk:Rhododendrites|talk]]</sup></samp> \\ 14:27, 23 October 2019 (UTC)}}

I appears to me that the most accurate way to describe the business this company does is a [[pawnbroker]] and I have added this link a few times to this article.  It is a clear from some of the references that the company does not like this term and there have been a number of attempts to remove this from the lead.  It may be this is from users that have connection to the company.  To make sure we keep a [[WP:NPOV]] it would be good other Wikipedia editors could comment on whether this term describes this business and is fair in this context. === [[Talk:2019 Canadian federal election#rfc_A574F59|Talk:2019 Canadian federal election]] expired 2019-11-23 15:01 ===
* Id: A574F59
* User: Brythones
* Date: 2019-10-24 14:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|922904424|POL 922904424}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|927598363|POL 927598363}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Canadian federal elections use the First Past the Post method of voting. Each riding elects one Member of Parliament (MP) based on the candidate who receives the highest number of votes in that area.

What is the most appropriate way of presenting Canadian election results in map form on Wikipedia?

Below are the three present templates:

* '''Template 1''' - Colour each riding by the colour of the elected MP's party. [[:File:Canada 2019 Preliminary.png]]
* '''Template 2''' - Detail party vote strength on the map and include seat names along the sides of the map. [[:File:Canadian Federal Election 2019 - Results by Riding.png]]
* '''Template 3''' - Use a provincial map of Canada, breaking down the results in graph form for each province. [[:File:Canada_2019_Federal_Election.svg]]
[[User:Brythones|Brythones]] ([[User talk:Brythones|talk]]) 14:02, 24 October 2019 (UTC)}}

* Id: 9AB626C
* User: Ladislav Mecir
* Date: 2019-11-25 16:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|927920320|ECON 927920320}}

{{rfcquote|text=
The source cited is a ''The Verge'' article authored by Adrianne Jeffries.<ref name="vergeonetrue">{{cite news |last1=Jeffries |first1=Adrianne |title=THE ONE TRUE BITCOIN - Inside the struggle between Bitcoin and Bitcoin Cash |url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/4/12/17229796/bitcoin-cash-conflict-transactions-fight |access-date=7 April 2019 |publisher=The Verge |date=12 April 2018}}</ref> The alternative formulations are:

#<blockquote>Some Bitcoin supporters like to call Bitcoin Cash "Bcash," "Btrash," or simply a scam, while Bitcoin Cash advocates insist that their implementation is the pure form of Bitcoin.</blockquote>
#<blockquote>Bitcoin Cash detractors call the cryptocurrency "Bcash," "Btrash," or "a scam", while its supporters maintain that "it is the pure form of bitcoin".</blockquote>

Which one of these alternatives is supported by the cited source? [[User:Ladislav Mecir|Ladislav Mecir]] ([[User talk:Ladislav Mecir|talk]]) 16:29, 25 November 2019 (UTC)}}

I would like to ask the help of the community to edit and add content to the page for completeness to increase its quality rating. Calling all researchers, writers and editors! Thanks. --[[User:KatherineBusby2019|KatherineBusby2019]] ([[User talk:KatherineBusby2019|talk]]) 15:50, 29 November 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Media bias against Bernie Sanders#rfc_4783364|Talk:Media bias against Bernie Sanders]] expired 2019-12-03 13:01 ===
* Id: 4783364
* User: Ellie.Michaels
* Date: 2019-12-01 16:53:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|928784313|POL 928784313}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|932542199|POL 932542199}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This article exhibits clear bias on the part of supporters of Bernie Sanders, as evidenced by the talk page and the content of the article itself. The main article for Bernie Sanders already contains a section dedicated to how he / his campaigns have been covered by news outlets. This page has no reason to exist other than to satisfy the agenda of Sanders supporters. 

Bernie Sanders receives a good deal of news coverage, and the coverage he gets tends to be somewhat positive. His supporters have created this article to abuse the clout of Wikipedia and justify their narrative that Sanders's current standing in the polls is due to outside forces rather than simply having less support than his opponents. The existence of a separate article also allows them to avoid the higher scrutiny they would face when editing the main article for Bernie Sanders. In addition, this seems to be the only page on the entirety of Wikipedia dedicated to the media bias against a single person. 

It is for these reasons that I believe this page should either be removed entirely, rolled into an existing section of the main Bernie Sanders article, or added as a new section of the main Bernie Sanders article. At the very least this article should be held to the same standard as any other political article, as political subjects are very easily affected by bias.

I apologize for any misuse of the Wikipedia editing process. I don't have any experience with this community, but had to speak out against what I feel is a clear abuse of the platform. 

[[User:Ellie.Michaels|Ellie.Michaels]] ([[User talk:Ellie.Michaels|talk]]) 16:53, 1 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Help talk:IPA/Standard German#rfc_E96DE43|Help talk:IPA/Standard German]] expired 2019-12-03 15:01 ===
* Id: E96DE43
* User: J. 'mach' wust
* Date: 2019-11-03 14:12:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|924385281|LANG 924385281}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|929079922|LANG 929079922}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
When we provide a German pronunciation for a topic related to Austria (or Switzerland), what variety of [[Standard German]] should we use? There are at least three options: use [[Austrian German|Austrian]] (or [[Swiss Standard German|Swiss]]) Standard German exclusively, use [[German Standard German]] exclusively, or use both. --[[User:J. 'mach' wust|mach]] [[User talk:J. 'mach' wust|&#x1f648;&#x1f649;&#x1f64a;]] 14:12, 3 November 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Islands#rfc_9156FCE|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Islands]] expired 2019-12-03 18:01 ===
* Id: 9156FCE
* User: Crouch, Swale
* Date: 2019-11-03 17:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|924409877|HIST 924409877}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|924409882|STYLE 924409882}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|929103088|HIST 929103088}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|929103100|STYLE 929103100}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
We sometimes use "on" for islands and other landforms for categories such as [[:Category:Villages on Jura, Scotland]] and [[:Category:Villages on the Isle of Mull]] and sometimes use "in" such as [[:Category:Villages in Islay]] and [[:Category:Villages in the Isle of Arran]].

Given the problems with the last one I'll start a brief one based on above with the "inhabited or previously inhabited".

*Always use "on".
*Use "in" for one of those size types (and larger, please specify the size such as "very small" per above) but otherwise use "on".
*Use "in" for inhabited or previously inhabited.
*Always use "in".

Arguments in favour of distinguishing from inhabited include being more natural (especially to the people there). Arguments against include determening if an island is/was inhabited. '''[[User:Crouch, Swale|<span style="color:Green">Crouch, Swale</span>]]''' ([[User talk:Crouch, Swale|<span style="color:Blue">talk</span>]])  17:25, 3 November 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_A7A4918|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2019-12-05 01:01 ===
* Id: A7A4918
* User: Dmehus
* Date: 2019-11-15 00:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|926228600|POLICY 926228600}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[Media Matters for America]] is a well-known partisan non-profit organization, linked and directly connected with multiple [[David Brock]]- and [[John Podesta]]-controlled [[Political action committee|political action committees (PACs)]]. So, on the same basis that we do not consider Republican or Democratic PACs to be notionally [[WP:RS|reliable sources]], I'm going to propose, again, that Media Matters' status as a reliable source to be changed to redlisted or blacklisted (whichever is preferred). --[[User:Dmehus|'''Doug Mehus''']]''<span style="font-size:small; vertical-align:top;">  [[User talk:Dmehus|T]]</span>''¬∑''<span style="font-size:small; vertical-align:bottom;">[[Special:Contributions/Dmehus|C]]</span>'' 00:16, 15 November 2019 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_23C927D|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2019-12-05 01:01 ===
* Id: 23C927D
* Date: 2019-11-05 00:53:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|924633112|MEDIA 924633112}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|924633123|PROP 924633123}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|929316100|MEDIA 929316100}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|929316117|PROP 929316117}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Newsweek has been discussed here several times this year (see [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_274#Newsweek] [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_270#Newsweek] [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_262#International_Business_Times]) but no real consensus around whether it is a reliable source has been reached. This RfC seeks to come to a consensus whether Newsweek is and ever was a reliable source. This is important as it is being used as a reference in thousands of articles {{duses|newsweek.com}}. This RfC is divided into two parts in order to find consensus. [[User:Barkeep49|Barkeep49]] ([[User_talk:Barkeep49|talk]]) 00:53, 5 November 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Social justice warrior#rfc_78A6C07|Talk:Social justice warrior]] expired 2019-12-05 07:01 ===
* Id: 78A6C07
* User: Bacondrum
* Date: 2019-12-03 21:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|928670308|POL 928670308}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|928676734|SOC 928676734}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|929350114|POL 929350114}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|929350116|SOC 929350116}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I believe that some recent good faith additions are unintentionally, but blatantly bias, and do not simply describe the subject but rather state as fact the negative attributes of those this term is used to denigrate. I also believe the citations used to do so are poor references for such bold claims, like suggesting that progressives are: 
:"pursuing personal validation in place of deep-seated conviction and engaging in disingenuous arguments." 
It reads as bias opinion and a misrepresentation of the source.
 
The same editor also added tangentially related topics (that might be appropriate in the see also section) to the lede claiming that: "It has been associated with being "woke" and call-out culture" they've added random quotes from Obama, Vice magazine contributors, some super obscure game etc. I feel like these and other recent edits are using POV language and drawing in as many negatives as possible rather than objectively describing the subject - a pejorative term used by detractors to describe progressives. 

I believe the language needs to be more neutral and reflect the sources, some claims are undue and/or based on low quality sources. What do other editors think? 
[[User:Bacondrum|Bacondrum]] ([[User talk:Bacondrum|talk]]) 21:09, 3 December 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Senate of Canada#rfc_38A7006|Template talk:Senate of Canada]] expired 2019-12-06 02:01 ===
* Id: 38A7006
* User: Dmehus
* Date: 2019-11-06 01:47:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|924808276|TECH 924808276}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|929473798|TECH 929473798}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hi everyone,

The [[:Template:Canadian federal political parties]] uses the [[:Template:Canadian party colour]] template, per [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Political parties and politicians in Canada/list of parties#Senate-only caucuses]] documentation. This template uses the more generic [[:Template:Party shading/Independent]], [[:Template:Party shading/Liberal]], and [[:Template:Party shading/Conservative]] templates. So, I propose, for the purposes of simplicity, streamlining, and using the Canadian context, that we update this template's party colour shading template to [[:Template:Canadian party colour]] as outlined in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Political parties and politicians in Canada/list of parties#Senate-only caucuses]] documentation.

- --[[User:Dmehus|Doug Mehus]] ([[User talk:Dmehus|talk]]) 01:47, 6 November 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Canadian Senators Group#rfc_C9C2F70|Talk:Canadian Senators Group]] expired 2019-12-07 03:01 ===
* Id: C9C2F70
* User: Dmehus
* Date: 2019-11-07 02:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|924984156|POL 924984156}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|924984159|SOC 924984159}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|929628941|POL 929628941}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|929628943|SOC 929628943}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Today, two different IP editors have tried adding [[Liberalism]]/[[Conservatism]] and [[Liberal Conservatism]] to the [[List of political ideologies|Ideology]] attribute to the [[Canadian Senators Group]], ''without'' providing a citation saying that these ideologies were official ideologies of the [[parliamentary group|parliamentary caucus]] in the [[Senate of Canada|Canadian Senate]].

The first editor did not provide an edit summary. Finally, the second IP editor claimed, in their edit summary, that because ''some'' of the group's Senators ''may'' have supported legislation or proposed legislation supported by the [[Conservative Party of Canada|Conservatives]], that that's enough to justify adding [[Liberal Conservatism]] or [[Conservatism]] as this group's ideology. I wholeheartedly disagree, so have reverted the edits, which I assume were in [[WP:AGF|good faith]], and have now initiated this [[WP:RFC|RFC]] to establish consensus that this was the correct approach. Otherwise, we'll have to start applying unofficial political ideologies to similar [[parliamentary group|parliamentary caucuses]] such the [[Independent Senators Group]].

'''To non-involved closing editor:''' Please ensure you close this with RfC with the ''optional'' top/bottom tags when consensus can be assessed. Thanks. --[[User:Dmehus|Doug Mehus]] ([[User talk:Dmehus|talk]]) 02:13, 7 November 2019 (UTC)}}

* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|925120919|MEDIA 925120919}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|925120920|SOC 925120920}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|929748841|MEDIA 929748841}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|929748846|SOC 929748846}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Proposal:''' Recommend ''deleting'' the sentence in [[Tucker Carlson Tonight]]'s "Criticism" section that reads, "By August 2019, Media Matters calculated that the show had lost more than 70 advertisers since December 2018[,][15]" where footnote # 15 is a link to a [[Media Matters]] site. [[Media Matters]] is '''not''' a [[WP:RS|reliable source]]; it is a biased [[Left-leaning|left-leaning]] propaganda website, funded by [[David Brock]]'s political action committee/politically-active non-profit conglomeration/empire. Alternatively, if there's a [[WP:RS|reliable source]], ideally two sources since it's a ''criticism'', that cites the same thing as [[Media Matters]] and which is '''not''' a [[WP:CIRCULAR|circular source reference]] that cites [[Media Matters]], I wouldn't be opposed to ''replacing'' the citation. But, ''as written'', this is a highly problematic citation.

Given the contentious nature of this show and the attention it attracts, I thought it prudent to establish this RfC to establish [[WP:CONSENSUS|consensus]] rather than editing out that sentence, only have to it be undone within days (if not sooner).--[[User:Dmehus|Doug Mehus]] ([[User talk:Dmehus|talk]]) 23:49, 7 November 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Username policy#rfc_605DBB7|Wikipedia talk:Username policy]] expired 2019-12-09 16:01 ===
* Id: 605DBB7
* User: Beeblebrox
* Date: 2019-11-09 15:22:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|925356528|POLICY 925356528}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|930000060|POLICY 930000060}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
&#32;
*{{tl|Uw-spamublock}}
*{{tl|Uw-softerblock}}
*{{tl|Uw-causeblock}}

Had a RL discussion yesterday about the message our blocking templates for [[WP:ORGNAME]] violations, and I think we may have hit on a real issue here. None of these templates mentions what we historically called the "Mark at Alcoa" exception, that is, adapting an orgname to an acceptable name by adding an unique identifier for an individual. 

What tends to happen now is that the user registers the organization name, (or the name of their PR agency working for that an organization) makes a draft or edits an article on that organization, and then gets blocked and told either it's because of their username or because of their username ''and'' spamming. The message they tend to get, whether intended or not, is "change your name and it's cool". And by the letter of our policy, this is true, at least for soft blocks. The issue is that if they go ahead and register a new, policy-compliant name, we no longer have that easy identifier that lets us know they have a [[WP:COI]] and/or are [[WP:PAID]]. This is not optimal. 

So what I'm suggesting is that we modify these templates to suggest they use the <name>@<organization> format. I'm not suggesting exact wording since every time I do that someone else has better wording, so I'll leave that to ya'll should we decide to do this. Thoughts? [[User:Beeblebrox|Beeblebrox]] ([[User talk:Beeblebrox|talk]]) 15:22, 9 November 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (television)#rfc_E704D3D|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (television)]] expired 2019-12-10 18:01 ===
* Id: E704D3D
* User: Gonnym
* Date: 2019-11-10 17:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|925525330|MEDIA 925525330}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|930168587|MEDIA 930168587}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Background: TV articles that need disambiguation can be disambiguated by the country adjective of the country the show originated from. So, as an example, if a show was broadcast in Mexico it would be <code>''TV series'' (Mexican TV series)</code>. Sub-divisions of a country are not used for disambiguating. Which means an article can be disambiguated as <code>''TV series'' (American TV series)</code> but not <code>''TV series'' (New York TV series)</code>; <code>''TV series'' (British TV series)</code>, but not <code>''TV series'' (Welsh TV series)</code>, <code>''TV series'' (Scottish TV series)</code> or <code>''TV series'' (Northern Ireland TV series)</code>.

The above discussion's input has the pre-1997 disambiguation for these articles at <code>''TV series'' (Hong Kong TV series)</code>. Should post-1997 TV articles about Hong Kong be disambiguated the same or use <code>''TV series'' (Chinese TV series)</code>. --[[User:Gonnym|Gonnym]] ([[User talk:Gonnym|talk]]) 17:20, 10 November 2019 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Maps#rfc_BF2445A|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Maps]] expired 2019-12-11 11:01 ===
* Id: BF2445A
* User: RaviC
* Date: 2019-11-11 10:48:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|925638762|HIST 925638762}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|930275357|HIST 930275357}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In articles on Wikipedia about political subdivisions with territorial disputes, it is common to show both the de-jure and de-facto boundaries of a division (see below).
<gallery>
File:Tibet_in_China_(claimed_hatched)_(+all_claims_hatched).svg|[[Tibet Autonomous Region]]
File:People's_Republic_of_China_-_Taiwan.svg|[[Taiwan Province, People's Republic of China]]
File:Nicosia_in_Cyprus.svg|[[Nicosia District]]
File:Famagusta_in_Cyprus.svg|[[Famagusta District]]
File:Crimea_in_Ukraine.svg|[[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]]
File:Argentina_-_Tierra_del_Fuego_Province_and_its_territorial_claims.svg|[[Tierra del Fuego Province, Argentina]]
File:P'y≈èngan-namdo_(ROK).jpg|[[South Pyeongan Province (Republic of Korea)]]
</gallery>
Following the bifurcation of the state of Jammu and Kashmir, I was asked to make some [[:File:IN-JK_(2019).svg|new]] [[:File:IN-LH.svg|maps]] showing these new divisions.  These were then cited by {{u|Kautilya3}} in a [[Talk:Jammu_and_Kashmir_(union_territory)#Three_map_proposal|discussion]] as "a good solution for avoiding objections from readers". Consequent to this, {{u|Fowler&fowler}} self-judged that my maps were POV and removed them from all articles present.

The question is very simply to establish a common consensus across Wikipedia on whether territorial claims should, or should not be present in any articles about political subdivisions. 

--[[User:RaviC|RaviC]] ([[User talk:RaviC|talk]]) 10:48, 11 November 2019 (UTC)}}
